Description: TABLE MOUNTAIN RANCHERIA WILL EXPAND ITS MUSEUM COLLECTIONS STORAGE CAPACITY TO ENHANCE ITS ABILITY TO SAFEGUARD TRIBAL CULTURE AND HISTORY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ACQUIRING A 40-FOOT INSULATED STORAGE CONTAINER AND PURCHASING AND INSTALLING THE NECESSARY SHELVING, LIGHTING, TEMPERATURE AND HUMIDITY CONTROL SYSTEMS AND MONITORS, AND SECURITY ELEMENTS FOR THE NEW SPACE. ONCE COMPLETED, THE PROJECT TEAM WILL REHOUSE COLLECTIONS ITEMS IN THE NEW FACILITY. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE TRIBE’S CURATION AND PRESERVATION PRACTICES, INCREASE ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS, AND CREATE MUCH-NEEDED ADDITIONAL SPACE FOR THE COLLECTIONS, HELPING TO PRESERVE AND SUSTAIN TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE FOR THE TRIBE AND CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS WHO VISIT AND LEARN FROM THE COLLECTIONS.

TABLE MOUNTAIN RANCHERIA WILL COMPLETE THE ASSEMBLY AND INSTALLATION OF TRADITIONAL STRUCTURES TO BE FEATURED ALONG THE TRIBE’S NATIVE PLANT TRAIL AT A HISTORIC YOKUTS VILLAGE SITE. THE OUTDOOR EXHIBIT STRUCTURES WILL BE CREATED USING TRADITIONAL METHODS IN A HANDS-ON COMMUNITY APPROACH LED BY NATIVE CONSULTANTS WHO WILL DEMONSTRATE, TEACH, AND SUPERVISE THE COMMUNITY PARTICIPANTS IN THE GATHERING, PREPARATION, AND ASSEMBLY OF MATERIALS. THROUGH CONSTRUCTING TRADITIONAL STRUCTURES FOUND IN LOCAL YOKUTS AND MONO VILLAGES OF THE PAST, THIS PROJECT WILL RECONNECT THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY WITH ITS CULTURE, HISTORY, AND LANGUAGES. THE COMPLETED OUTDOOR EXHIBIT WILL BE AN IMMERSIVE AND EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE BENEFITING TRIBAL FAMILIES AND YOUTH, AS WELL AS NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE VISITORS FROM FRESNO COUNTY AND BEYOND.

THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE UMATILLA INDIAN RESERVATION WILL COMMEMORATE THE 25TH ANNIVERSARY OF THE OPENING OF ITS TAMASTSLIKT CULTURAL INSTITUTE (TCI) BY UPDATING OUTDATED SECTIONS OF ITS PERMANENT EXHIBITION, ENHANCING COLLECTIONS CARE AND ACCESS, AND INVESTING IN THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OF ITS STAFF. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HIRING A CONSERVATION TECHNICIAN, PURCHASING ARCHIVAL SUPPLIES TO PROPERLY STORE AND DISPLAY COLLECTION ITEMS, AND SUBSCRIBING TO A NEW COLLECTIONS SOFTWARE OPTION THAT WILL ALLOW TCI TO SHARE ITS COLLECTIONS ONLINE. PROJECT FUNDS WILL ALSO BE USED TO INVEST IN TECHNOLOGY ENHANCEMENTS, SUPPORT TRAINING FOR NEWLY HIRED STAFF MEMBERS, AND CONTRACT WITH AN EXHIBITION DESIGN FIRM THAT WILL DESIGN, FABRICATE, AND INSTALL FRESH CONTENT AND DISPLAYS FOR TCI’S PERMANENT EXHIBITION. ALL OF THESE ACTIVITIES WILL IMPROVE TCI'S CAPACITY TO PROVIDE MUSEUM SERVICES TO TRIBAL MEMBERS, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND THE PUBLIC.

THE HAWAIʻI STATE ARCHIVES WILL DIGITIZE OVER 100,000 NEGATIVES FROM TWO OF THE PREMIER ARCHITECTURAL PHOTOGRAPHERS OF THE LATTER 20TH CENTURY, DAVID FRANZEN AND NANCY BANNICK, AND MAKE THEM FREELY ACCESSIBLE IN A BILINGUAL (HAWAIIAN LANGUAGE AND ENGLISH) ONLINE DATABASE. THREE PAID GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS WILL BE HIRED AND TRAINED TO CREATE HIGH RESOLUTION DIGITAL FILES FOR OVER 40 BOXES OF PHOTOGRAPHS, SLIDES, AND PRINTS AS WELL AS CLEAN, TRANSCRIBE, AND TRANSLATE DESCRIPTIVE METADATA. THIS NEWLY DIGITIZED BILINGUAL ARCHIVE WILL SERVE AS A VISUAL RECORD OF THE “HAWAIʻI THAT WAS,” PROVIDING WORLDWIDE ACCESS TO HAWAIIAN ARCHITECTURAL HISTORY AND HERITAGE, AS WELL AS PROTECTING THESE IRREPLACEABLE MATERIALS FROM CONTINUED DETERIORATION AND EVENTUAL LOSS.

THE TWENTY-NINE PALMS BAND OF MISSION INDIANS WILL CONTINUE ITS PLANNING EFFORTS FOR A FUTURE CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM BY DEVELOPING AN ORGANIZATIONAL PLAN THAT ADDRESSES THE GOVERNANCE, OPERATIONS, AND STAFFING NEEDS FOR THE MUSEUM. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ENGAGING A PROFESSIONAL MUSEUM CONSULTANT WHO WILL CONVENE AND COORDINATE AN ORGANIZATIONAL COMMITTEE COMPRISED OF TRIBAL STAFF, TRIBAL MEMBERS, CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS, AND ORGANIZATIONAL PARTNERS TO DEVELOP THE ORGANIZATIONAL PLAN. THE RESULTING PLAN WILL BE USED TO BUILD THE FOUNDATION OF A MUSEUM THAT IS SUSTAINABLY OPERATED, HELPING TO ENSURE THAT IT CAN SUCCESSFULLY BECOME A PLACE OF LEARNING, PRESERVATION, AND HEALING FOR THE TRIBE AND THE VISITING PUBLIC.

HIʻIPAKA LLC WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE A MULTI-SENSUAL MUSEUM EXHIBIT AT A RESTORED TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN LIVING SITE IN WAIMEA VALLEY, FEATURING SEVEN HALE (TRADITIONAL HOUSES OR STRUCTURES) STAGED WITH TRADITIONAL IMPLEMENTS AND AUDIO RECORDINGS OF DAILY LIFE, HAWAIIAN LANGUAGE, AND EXPOSITORY NARRATION. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE ENGAGING LOCAL ARTISANS TO REPRODUCE TRADITIONAL TOOLS FOR DISPLAY IN THE RESTORED HALE AS WELL AS DRAFTING AND RECORDING AUDIO NARRATIVES FOR THE HALE. THE RESULTING EXHIBITS WILL PROVIDE A MORE INCLUSIVE EDUCATIONAL EXPERIENCE THAT ENGAGES ALL FIVE SENSES, CREATING AN IMMERSIVE AND AUTHENTIC OPPORTUNITY TO LEARN ABOUT NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURE FOR K-12 STUDENTS, LOCAL RESIDENTS, AND WAIMEA VALLEY VISITORS.

THE MECHOOPDA INDIAN TRIBE WILL UNDERTAKE EFFORTS TO PRESERVE AND PERPETUATE THE MAIDU LANGUAGE IN RESPONSE TO THE LOSS OF ONE OF THE TRIBE’S LAST FLUENT MAIDU SPEAKERS TO COVID-19. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT HIRING A FULL-TIME PROJECT COORDINATOR WHO WILL COLLECT AND CREATE NEW CONTENT FOR THE TRIBE’S FREE MAIDU LANGUAGE APP; DEVELOP NEW MAIDU CLASSES, WORKSHOPS, AND PROGRAMS; AND UPDATE SIGNAGE IN EXHIBITS AND DISPLAYS AT THE TRIBAL ADMINISTRATIVE OFFICES TO INCLUDE MAIDU. THIS TIMELY INITIATIVE TO DOCUMENT, SHARE, AND INCORPORATE MAIDU BEFORE MORE KNOWLEDGE IS LOST WILL HELP PRESERVE AND PERPETUATE THE MAIDU LANGUAGE FOR THE NEXT GENERATION OF MECHOOPDA PEOPLE.

THE CATAWBA CULTURAL CENTER, COMPRISED OF THE CATAWBA INDIAN NATION’S MUSEUM, LIBRARY, AND ARCHIVES, WILL DESIGN AND IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF PROGRAMS TO PROMOTE THE IMPORTANCE OF PRESERVING AND CELEBRATING TRADITIONAL CATAWBA CULTURE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A SUMMER READING PROGRAM FOR CATAWBA CHILDREN, LAUNCHING A YEAR-ROUND CULTURAL HERITAGE PROGRAMMING SCHEDULE FOR CATAWBA COMMUNITY MEMBERS OF ALL AGES, AND PURCHASING NECESSARY EQUIPMENT, SOFTWARE, AND SUPPLIES TO DIGITIZE OBJECTS USING 3D PHOTOGRAMMETRY TECHNOLOGY. DIGITIZED OBJECTS WILL BE MADE ACCESSIBLE ONLINE, ALLOWING GREATER ACCESS FOR RESEARCH AND PROGRAMMING PURPOSES WHILE REDUCING PHYSICAL HANDLING, WHICH WILL IN TURN SUPPORT PRESERVATION EFFORTS. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP BUILD A FOUNDATION FOR LIFELONG LEARNING, INCREASE UNDERSTANDING OF CATAWBA CULTURE AND HERITAGE, AND HELP PRESERVE THAT HERITAGE FOR THE CATAWBA COMMUNITY.

THE CENTRAL COUNCIL TLINGIT AND HAIDA INDIAN TRIBES OF ALASKA WILL SUPPORT ONGOING COLLECTIONS CARE AND ACCESS EFFORTS FOR HISTORIC SACRED AND CEREMONIAL ITEMS THAT HAVE BEEN REPATRIATED TO THE TRIBE. THE PROJECT WILL ENABLE THE PURCHASE OF MUSEUM SUPPLIES AND HIGH-QUALITY PROTECTIVE CASES SO THE REPATRIATED OBJECTS CAN BE SAFELY TRANSPORTED TO CULTURAL EVENTS IN THEIR RESPECTIVE SOUTHEAST ALASKAN COMMUNITIES. PROJECT FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE TRIBE’S CULTURAL RESOURCES SPECIALIST, WHO IS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE CARETAKING AND TRANSPORT OF THESE OBJECTS, SOME OF WHICH DATE TO THE 1800’S AND EARLIER. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, TLINGIT AND HAIDA PEOPLES OF SOUTHEAST ALASKA WILL HAVE INCREASED ACCESS TO THEIR CULTURAL ITEMS, HELPING PRESERVE AND PERPETUATE TRADITIONAL CEREMONIES AND LIFEWAYS, WHILE THE ITEMS THEMSELVES WILL BE BETTER PROTECTED FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE ILANKA CULTURAL CENTER WILL FURTHER ITS MISSION TO EDUCATE ITS COMMUNITY AND VISITORS WHILE PERPETUATING THE TRADITIONS, SKILLS, AND CULTURES OF THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF EYAK BY CREATING SIX CHILDREN'S PICTURE BOOKS DEPICTING TRADITIONAL EYAK AND CHUGACH LEGENDS. PROJECT STAFF WILL HIRE SIX TRIBAL ARTISTS TO PROVIDE ILLUSTRATIONS FOR THE LEGENDS AND WILL OVERSEE DESIGN AND PUBLICATION OF APPROXIMATELY 450 COPIES OF THE BOOKS. THE PUBLISHED BOOKS WILL BE MADE AVAILABLE AT THE CULTURAL CENTER, AS WELL AS DISSEMINATED FREE OF COST THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY, INCLUDING TO TRIBAL HOUSEHOLDS WITH YOUTH AND THE CORDOVA PUBLIC LIBRARY. AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT, TRIBAL FAMILIES WILL HAVE A NEW ENGAGING MEDIUM FOR PASSING DOWN ORAL TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE AND TRIBAL ARTISTS’ WORK WILL BE SUPPORTED AND SHOWCASED.

THE KAHO‘OLAWE ISLAND RESERVE COMMISSION WILL DEVELOP A DIGITAL APPLICATION TO COLLECT AND MANAGE RELEVANT CULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL INFORMATION RELATED TO THE RESTORATION OF KAHO‘OLAWE ISLAND. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING, TESTING, AND IMPLEMENTING COLLECTION PROTOCOLS FOR GATHERING DATA THROUGH CULTURAL AND TRADITIONAL PRACTICES, DEVELOPING THE DIGITAL APPLICATION AND DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, AND PROVIDING STAFF TRAINING ON DATA COLLECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND DIGITAL APPLICATION USE. THE RESULTING APP AND RELATED PROTOCOLS WILL ALLOW USERS TO RECORD, COLLECT, AND ORGANIZE CONSISTENT AND ACCURATE DATA IN REAL TIME, AND IN A STANDARDIZED FORMAT, MAKING IT MORE MANAGEABLE AND EASIER TO ANALYZE BY CURRENT AND FUTURE CULTURAL AND ENVIRONMENTAL STEWARDS OF KAHO‘OLAWE. AS A RESULT, THE OVERALL CARE, MANAGEMENT, AND USE OF THE ENVIRONMENTAL, HISTORICAL, ARCHEOLOGICAL, AND CULTURAL RESOURCES ON KAHO‘OLAWE WILL IMPROVE.

THE LĀNAʻI CULTURE AND HERITAGE CENTER WILL CONDUCT A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROJECT TO ENHANCE THE CARE OF AND ACCESS TO 2,500 NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL OBJECTS IN ITS COLLECTION. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING A COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICY; CONDUCTING A COMPREHENSIVE COLLECTIONS INVENTORY; CATALOGING AND DIGITIZING THE INVENTORIED COLLECTION; ACQUIRING AND INSTALLING COMPACT MOBILE SHELVING; AND REHOUSING THE COLLECTIONS. PROJECT FUNDS WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE PURCHASE OF NECESSARY SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT, THE RECRUITMENT AND TRAINING OF PAID INTERNS, AND THE ENGAGEMENT OF A CONSULTING ARCHIVIST WHO WILL TRAVEL TO THE CENTER TO PROVIDE OVERSIGHT ON THE DEVELOPMENT OF CATALOGING PROTOCOLS AND STANDARDS FOR DIGITAL ASSET MANAGEMENT. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THE COLLECTION, BENEFITTING BOTH THE LOCAL LĀNAʻI COMMUNITY, AND THE BROADER NATIVE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITY.

PAPAHANA KUAOLA WILL PARTNER WITH CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS AND ANOTHER NATIVE HAWAIIAN-SERVING ORGANIZATION, PAEPAE O HEʻEIA, TO DEVELOP A PLACE-BASED LEARNING PROGRAM THAT PRESERVES, PERPETUATES, AND PRACTICES THE ART OF KŪKULU HALE (BUILDING TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN STRUCTURES). THE PROJECT TEAM WILL TRAIN PAPAHANA KUAOLA STAFF AND HIGH SCHOOL INTERNS IN UTILIZING TRADITIONAL AND MODERN TECHNIQUES TO CONSTRUCT A TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN HALE. THE TEAM WILL ALSO DEVELOP AND DELIVER HANDS-ON COMMUNITY PROGRAMS AIMED AT TEACHING INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND VISITING SCHOOL GROUPS THE HISTORY AND TECHNIQUES OF INDIGENOUS HAWAIIAN ARCHITECTURE. THE RESULTING HALE WILL SERVE AS A COMMUNITY GATHERING PLACE, WHILE STAFF AND PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS WILL ACQUIRE KNOWLEDGE AND SKILLS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL IN PERPETUATING THIS TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN PRACTICE.

KAʻALA FARM WILL DEVELOP AND PROVIDE FIBER ARTS WORKSHOPS THAT DISCUSS THE ROLE OF FIBER ARTS IN HAWAIIAN HISTORY AND MOʻOLELO (STORIES) AND OFFER HANDS-ON OPPORTUNITIES TO GAIN SKILLS IN THIS IMPORTANT NATIVE HAWAIIAN ART FORM. PROJECT STAFF WILL IDENTIFY AND HIRE FIBER ARTS PRACTITIONERS TO LEAD PROGRAMS, COORDINATE RECRUITMENT FOR PARTICIPATION IN PILOT WORKSHOPS, AND EVALUATE AND REFINE THE CONTENT BEFORE LAUNCHING IT TO WIDER AUDIENCES. THE RESULTING PROGRAMS WILL CREATE OPPORTUNITIES FOR A BROADER AND DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF THE ANCESTRAL AND CONTEMPORARY HISTORY OF NATIVE HAWAIIANS IN GENERAL, AND THE NATIVE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITY OF WAIʻANAE IN PARTICULAR. THROUGH THIS PROJECT, STUDENTS, ELDERS, FAMILIES, AND OTHER PARTICIPANTS WILL HAVE THE OPPORTUNITY TO ENGAGE WITH HAWAIIAN HISTORY AND THIS ART FORM FROM A NATIVE HAWAIIAN PERSPECTIVE.

THE BAD RIVER BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR TRIBE OF CHIPPEWA INDIANS WILL CONTINUE ITS EFFORTS TO ESTABLISH ITS NEW MOKA’AANGIIZIS-IBAN (RISING SUN) TRIBAL MUSEUM BY IMPLEMENTING A COMMUNITY-DRIVEN INSTITUTIONAL PLANNING AND POLICY DEVELOPMENT PROJECT. THE MUSEUM MANAGER WILL CREATE A 5-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN AND DRAFT POLICIES THAT ESTABLISH A STRONG FOUNDATION FOR MUSEUM ORGANIZATION, COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP, EDUCATION AND INTERPRETATION, AND COMMUNITY AND AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RESEARCHING BEST PRACTICES, INFORMATION GATHERING THROUGH COMMUNITY SURVEYS AND FOCUS GROUPS, AND CONDUCTING SITE VISITS TO MUSEUMS OF SIMILAR SCOPE AND MISSION. DEVELOPING THESE FOUNDATIONAL DOCUMENTS WILL INCREASE THE MUSEUM’S CAPACITY TO SERVE ITS COMMUNITY AND CREATE A PATH FORWARD FOR MUSEUM OPERATION AND GROWTH THAT IS ROOTED IN TRIBAL VALUES.

THE LAC COURTE OREILLES (LCO) TRIBAL MUSEUM AND VISITOR CENTER WILL PARTNER WITH LCO OJIBWE SCHOOLS, AND THE LCO OJIBWE UNIVERSITY COMMUNITY LIBRARY TO CREATE A PROJECT-BASED LEARNING PROGRAM FOR 8TH TO 10TH GRADE STUDENTS. THE TRIBE WILL HIRE A PROJECT COORDINATOR WHO WILL SERVE AS A LIAISON BETWEEN THE MUSEUM, LIBRARY, AND LCO SCHOOLS, AND WILL DEVELOP AND CONDUCT INSTRUCTIONAL PROGRAMMING UTILIZING PRIMARY SOURCE DOCUMENTS AND ARTIFACTS. THROUGH COLLABORATIVE RESOURCE-SHARING, LCO INSTITUTIONS WILL PROVIDE OPPORTUNITIES THAT CONNECT OJIBWE STUDENTS WITH THEIR HERITAGE IN A MEANINGFUL CONTEXT. AS A RESULT, THE PROJECT WILL DEEPEN STUDENTS’ APPRECIATION OF CULTURAL PRACTICES AND THEIR VALUE AND FURTHER TRIBAL-WIDE EFFORTS TO PRESERVE OJIBWE HISTORY, CULTURE, AND LANGUAGE.

THE MYAAMIA HERITAGE MUSEUM & ARCHIVE WILL REVAMP AND INSTALL ITS COMMUNITY CURATED MYAAMIA RIBBONWORK EXHIBIT. FIRST DISPLAYED AT THE MIAMI UNIVERSITY ART MUSEUM, THE EXHIBIT’S ORIGINAL RUN WAS CUT SHORT BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT PHYSICAL IMPROVEMENTS TO THE TRIBAL MUSEUM’S EXHIBITION GALLERY, INCLUDING UPGRADING LIGHTING AND PURCHASING AND INSTALLING NEW DISPLAY CASES, IN ORDER TO SAFELY EXHIBIT EARLY 19TH CENTURY RIBBONWORK OBJECTS. ADDITIONAL PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE SECURING LOANS OF HISTORIC RIBBONWORK OBJECTS, PLANNING AND INSTALLING THE EXHIBITION, AND ENGAGING THE COMMUNITY THROUGH OUTREACH ACTIVITIES AND EDUCATIONAL EVENTS. THE EXHIBIT WILL BENEFIT THE CITIZENS OF THE MIAMI TRIBE OF OKLAHOMA BY CREATING AN ADDITIONAL OPPORTUNITY TO SHARE CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE AND WILL CONTINUE COMMUNITY EFFORTS TO REVITALIZE MYAAMIA RIBBONWORK.

WAIʻANAE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL WILL IMPLEMENT A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM FOR 30 NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS TO HELP PROMOTE THE ECONOMIC WELL-BEING OF NATIVE HAWAIIANS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THE ORGANIZATION WILL DELIVER A HAWAIIAN CULTURE-BASED ENTREPRENEURSHIP WORKSHOP SERIES TO THE PRACTITIONERS AND PROVIDE THEM WITH THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE NEEDED TO CREATE ONLINE LEARNING CONTENT. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE RECRUITING PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS, DEVELOPING AND PROVIDING WORKSHOPS, AND DESIGNING, RECORDING, AND PUBLISHING DIGITAL CONTENT. THIS PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC ACCESS TO NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE AND PRACTICES WHILE BUILDING THE BUSINESS AND TECHNICAL CAPACITY OF CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS SO THAT THEY MAY BETTER SUSTAIN THEMSELVES, THEIR FAMILIES, AND THEIR COMMUNITIES.

THE CHOCTAW CULTURAL CENTER WILL PRESERVE COLLECTIONS AND PERPETUATE TRADITIONAL CULTURAL PRACTICES BY RECREATING AT-RISK TEXTILES AND PROVIDING PROGRAMMING FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO LEARN ABOUT CHOCTAW TEXTILE PRACTICES. THE CENTER WILL COLLABORATE WITH CHOCTAW TRADITIONAL ARTISANS, WHO WILL CREATE 10 TO 15 DUPLICATE TEXTILE ITEMS TO BE USED FOR DISPLAY ROTATION, HELPING TO COMBAT DETERIORATION AND STRAIN ON TEXTILES FEATURED IN THE CENTER’S PERMANENT EXHIBIT. THE CENTER WILL ALSO EXPAND UPON ITS CURRENT PUBLIC PROGRAMMING BY OFFERING MASTERCLASS OPPORTUNITIES WITH THE ARTISANS AND ADDITIONAL EDUCATIONAL SEMINARS AND DEMONSTRATIONS FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS, STUDENTS, TEACHERS, AND THE COMMUNITY. AS A RESULT, COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BE MORE KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT TRADITIONAL CHOCTAW TEXTILES AND THE LIVES OF CURRENT COLLECTION ITEMS WILL BE EXTENDED FOR CONTINUED DISPLAY.

THE IOWA TRIBE OF KANSAS AND NEBRASKA WILL ADDRESS CHALLENGES IT FACES IN OPERATING ITS NEWLY OPENED IOWA AND SAC & FOX MISSION MUSEUM, NAMELY, LACK OF ACCESS TO ARTIFACTS RELATED TO THE MISSION AND TRIBE’S HISTORY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY AND DOCUMENT CULTURALLY SIGNIFICANT ITEMS AND ARTWORK HELD BY NON-TRIBAL ENTITIES AND PARTNER WITH THOSE ENTITIES TO PHOTOGRAPH AND DIGITIZE THOSE ITEMS. MUSEUM STAFF WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING AND PURCHASE NECESSARY COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE AND EQUIPMENT, BUILDING THE TRIBE’S CAPACITY TO PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL MUSEUM SERVICES. THE RESULTING VIRTUAL REPOSITORY WILL BENEFIT TRIBAL MEMBERS, STUDENTS, EDUCATORS, AND RESEARCHERS BY PROVIDING GREATER ACCESS TO IOWA AND SAC & FOX HISTORICAL INFORMATION AND MATERIAL CULTURE.

THE NOTTAWASEPPI HURON BAND OF THE POTAWATOMI WILL PARTNER WITH THE BATTLE CREEK REGIONAL HISTORY MUSEUM IN BATTLE CREEK, MI TO CREATE A NEW CULTURAL HERITAGE LOBBY AT THE MUSEUM TO ADDRESS A GENERAL LACK OF EDUCATION AND AWARENESS ABOUT LOCAL TRIBAL HISTORY AND CULTURAL HERITAGE. THE RE-DESIGNED LOBBY WILL DISPLAY AN ORIGINAL MURAL BY A POTAWATOMI ARTIST, AS WELL AS THREE KIOSKS SET WITHIN CUSTOMIZED DECORATIVE BASES, SHOWCASING DIGITAL IMAGES AND CONTENT DISCUSSING POTAWATOMI HISTORY, LANGUAGE, AND LIFEWAYS. PROJECT FUNDS WILL COVER EXHIBITION CONTENT AND GRAPHIC DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT, REVIEW, AND APPROVAL, AS WELL AS THE KIOSK FABRICATION AND INSTALLATION. BY FEATURING NATIVE VOICES AND MATERIALS, THE NEW LOBBY EXHIBIT WILL HELP INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF LOCAL TRIBAL HISTORY AND CULTURE FOR BOTH TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL CITIZENS OF SOUTHWESTERN MICHIGAN.

THE GUN LAKE TRIBE WILL DEVELOP AND ENHANCE EXISTING AND UNDERUTILIZED EXHIBIT AREAS WITHIN THREE TRIBAL FACILITIES WITH THE DUAL GOAL OF IMPROVING THE CARE OF AND INCREASING COMMUNITY ACCESS TO MATERIALS FROM THE TRIBE’S ARCHIVES AND COLLECTIONS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PURCHASING AND INSTALLING CLIMATE-CONTROLLED DISPLAY CASES, INSTALLING UV PROTECTION ON WINDOWS IN PUBLIC EXHIBIT AREAS, UPDATING EXHIBIT CONTENT WITH COMMUNITY INPUT, UPGRADING TO DIGITAL SIGNAGE, AND IDENTIFYING NEW OBJECTS FOR DISPLAY. THE UPDATED EXHIBITS WILL BETTER PROTECT AND PRESERVE THE TRIBE’S CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS, AS WELL AS INCREASE AWARENESS OF AND ENGAGEMENT WITH THE COLLECTIONS FOR TRIBAL CITIZENS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND NON-TRIBAL VISITORS.

THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF KWINHAGAK, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NUNALLEQ MUSEUM IN QUINHAGAK, AK, WILL CREATE A DIGITAL MUSEUM GUIDE TO FACILITATE ON-SITE VISITOR EXPERIENCE OF THE MUSEUM’S ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTION. THE DIGITAL GUIDE WILL FEATURE A RESPONSIVE MOBILE APPLICATION CONTAINING A SELECTION OF INTERACTIVE 3D ARTIFACTS FROM THE COLLECTION TOGETHER WITH CO-CURATED INTERPRETATIVE CONTENT FROM CLIMATE SCIENTISTS, ARCHAEOLOGISTS, YUP’IK CULTURE BEARERS, ARTISTS, AND ELDERS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE GATHERING RESOURCES FOR INCLUSION IN THE GUIDE, DEVELOPING THE BACK-END DATA STRUCTURE, PROTOTYPING AND BETA TESTING THE MOBILE APPLICATION, AND COLLECTING COMMUNITY FEEDBACK. AS A RESULT, THIS HISTORICALLY AND SCIENTIFICALLY SIGNIFICANT COLLECTION OF YUP’IK MATERIALS WILL BE BETTER PRESERVED, WHILE ALSO MORE ACCESSIBLE AND ENGAGING FOR MUSEUM VISITORS.

HULA PRESERVATION SOCIETY WILL DEVELOP FIVE VIRTUAL EXHIBITIONS THAT WILL ENABLE INCREASED INSIGHT AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE 20TH CENTURY IN HAWAIʻI. PROJECT STAFF AND PAID INTERNS WILL GATHER CONTENT AND DEVELOP THE DIGITAL INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE FIVE VIRTUAL EXHIBITS USING THE EXTENSIVE RESOURCES AVAILABLE IN THE SOCIETY’S DIGITAL ARCHIVES, DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ASSOCIATED PUBLIC PROGRAMMING, AND LAUNCH A RELATED SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP ADDRESS MISCONCEPTIONS ABOUT HAWAIʻI HISTORY AND CULTURE BY PROVIDING INCREASED ACCESS TO AND INTERPRETATION OF OVER 700 MULTI-FORMAT PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIALS AND WILL BENEFIT NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE HAWAIIANS ALIKE BY PROVIDING AN OPPORTUNITY TO EXPERIENCE HAWAIʻI THROUGH THE EYES, HEADS, AND HEARTS OF NATIVE HAWAIIANS.

THE INSTITUTE FOR NATIVE PACIFIC EDUCATION AND CULTURE (INPEACE) WILL DEVELOP AND DESIGN PLANS FOR A NEW LAWAIʻA (FISHING) STEM EXHIBIT THAT WILL HIGHLIGHT AND REINTRODUCE NATIVE HAWAIIAN FISHING TOOLS, STRATEGIES, AND TECHNIQUES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONSULTING WITH CULTURAL EXPERTS AND RESEARCHERS TO GATHER INFORMATION TO CREATE A REPOSITORY OF MATERIALS ABOUT NATIVE HAWAIIAN FISHING PRACTICES; CREATE A DESIGN REFERENCE GUIDE; DEVELOP CONCEPTUAL PLANS WITH COMMUNITY AND DESIGN EXPERTS; AND REFINE AND COMPLETE EXHIBIT LAYOUTS, SPECIFICATIONS, AND MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF THE TRADITIONAL AND CONTEMPORARY SCIENCE OF NATIVE HAWAIIAN FISHING PRACTICES WHILE SUPPORTING INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES IN CULTIVATING STRATEGIES TO DEVELOP CULTURALLY RELEVANT AND INFORMED STEM EXPERIENCES.

KAWAIAHA'O CHURCH, HOUSED IN THE FIRST CHRISTIAN CHURCH BUILT ON OʻAHU, WILL HIRE AN ARCHIVIST TO OVERSEE THE MANAGEMENT OF ITS HISTORICAL SITES AND ARCHIVE LIBRARY AS THE CHURCH UNDERTAKES A MOLD REMEDIATION PROJECT. THE ARCHIVIST WILL HELP COORDINATE THE RELOCATION OF THE ARCHIVAL COLLECTION, OVERSEE CONTRACTORS PERFORMING MOLD REMEDIATION, AND WORK WITH THE PROJECT TEAM TO CONTINUE PROCESSING THE COLLECTIONS THROUGH ACTIVITIES SUCH AS CATALOGING, DIGITIZATION, AND RE-HOUSING. THEY WILL ALSO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICIES AND PROCEDURES TO SUPPORT THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION AND CARE OF THIS HISTORICAL COLLECTION. AS A RESULT, NATIVE HAWAIIANS AND THE LARGER HAWAIʻI COMMUNITY WILL HAVE INCREASED ACCESS TO IMPORTANT CULTURAL AND HISTORICAL RECORDS, WHICH WILL BE BETTER PRESERVED FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS.

THE CHICKASAW NATION WILL PARTNER WITH THE FIRST AMERICANS MUSEUM IN OKLAHOMA CITY, OK TO DEVELOP A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE TEMPLATE THAT WILL PROVIDE K-12 EDUCATORS WITH A CENTRALIZED RESOURCE FOR EDUCATIONAL CURRICULUM INFORMED BY OKLAHOMAN TRIBAL NATIONS. PROJECT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT A DIGITAL STRATEGY CONSULTANT WHO WILL CONDUCT A REQUIREMENTS REVIEW, GATHER AND INVENTORY ASSETS, AND DEVELOP INFORMATION ARCHITECTURE, AS WELL AS A FULL-TIME PROJECT COORDINATOR WHO WILL ENGAGE WITH DIVERSE STAKEHOLDERS TO COLLABORATE ON THE CREATION OF A COMPREHENSIVE PLAN FOR THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EDUCATOR RESOURCE. THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN PROFESSIONAL RELATIONSHIPS AMONGST TRIBAL NATIONS AND EDUCATORS IN OKLAHOMA AND WILL INCREASE TRIBAL CAPACITY TO PROVIDE INTERACTIVE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ONLINE, ENSURING THE HISTORIES AND CULTURES OF OKLAHOMA’S TRIBES ARE ACCURATELY PORTRAYED, RESPECTED, AND SHARED IN THE CLASSROOM.

THE FOREST COUNTY POTAWATOMI COMMUNITY CULTURAL CENTER, LIBRARY & MUSEUM WILL FABRICATE AND INSTALL TWO NEWLY DESIGNED OUTDOOR EXHIBITS AND PROVIDE RELATED PROGRAMMING TO RE-ENGAGE THE COMMUNITY IN THE WAKE OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE MUSEUM WILL FABRICATE AN AUTHENTIC MEDICINAL GARDEN AND TEACHING LODGE EXHIBIT USING TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE AND TECHNIQUES AS WELL AS COLLABORATE WITH TRIBAL ELDERS TO DEVELOP CULTURALLY SPECIFIC HANDS-ON EXPERIENCES FOR THE NEW SPACES. BY PROVIDING NEW IMMERSIVE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES ABOUT LIVING POTAWATOMI CULTURE AND TRADITIONS, THIS PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN INCREASE IN COMMUNITY MEMBER PARTICIPATION IN MUSEUM PROGRAMMING AND WILL BENEFIT TRIBAL MEMBERS, DESCENDANTS, AND THEIR FAMILIES.

THE BAY MILLS INDIAN COMMUNITY WILL RECRUIT AND HIRE A FULL-TIME STAFF PERSON TO ORGANIZE, CATALOG, AND DIGITIZE THE TRIBAL HISTORY DEPARTMENT'S COLLECTION OF ARTIFACTS, PHOTOS, AND DOCUMENTS. ONCE INVENTORIED AND ORGANIZED, THE HISTORICAL COLLECTIONS WILL BE MORE ACCESSIBLE TO TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND WILL BE USED TO SHARE ACCURATE AND CULTURALLY RELEVANT HISTORY WITH VISITORS AT THE POINT IROQUOIS LIGHTHOUSE MUSEUM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO DEVELOP A POLICIES AND PROCEDURES MANUAL FOR HANDLING, INVENTORYING, AND FILING HISTORICAL DOCUMENTS, RESULTING IN THE TRIBE BEING BETTER-ABLE TO PROTECT AND CONSERVE IMPORTANT CULTURAL AND HISTORIC ASSETS.

HUI MAULI OLA WILL PARTNER WITH NATIVE HAWAIIAN HEALING MASTERS TO ETHICALLY GATHER, STORE, ORGANIZE, CURATE, AND MAKE ACCESSIBLE DOCUMENTS AND RESOURCES PERTAINING TO TRADITIONAL NATIVE HAWAIIAN HEALING PRACTICES VIA A DIGITAL ARCHIVE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DEVELOPING PROTOCOLS FOR ETHICAL DATA STEWARDSHIP DETERMINED BY THE NATIVE HAWAIIAN HEALING COMMUNITY; COLLECTING AND DIGITIZING MATERIALS FOR INCLUSION IN THE DATABASE; AND DEVELOPING AND PUBLISHING THE DIGITAL ARCHIVE. THE PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH A FOUNDATIONAL SYSTEM OF DOCUMENTING AND TRACING NATIVE HAWAIIAN TRADITIONAL HEALING KNOWLEDGE WHILE INCREASING NATIVE HAWAIIAN ARCHIVAL INFRASTRUCTURE CAPACITY, BENEFITING STUDENTS, THE COMMUNITY OF HAWAI‘I, NATIVE HAWAIIANS, AND OTHER PACIFIC ISLANDERS.

THE BISHOP MUSEUM WILL IMPLEMENT A PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM FOR MUSEUM STAFF AT SMALL AND MID-SIZED MUSEUMS IN HAWAI‘I TO ADDRESS THE NEED FOR MENTORSHIP AND TRAINING AND TO BUILD AN ONGOING NETWORK FOR PEER LEARNING AND SUPPORT FOR MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS IN HAWAI‘I. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE DESIGNING, DEVELOPING, AND DELIVERING A MENTORSHIP PROGRAM TO COHORTS OF MULTIPLE PARTICIPANTS THAT IS TARGETED TOWARDS UNDERSTANDING THE NON-PROFIT CULTURE IN HAWAI‘I, AND CUSTOMIZED TO THE NEEDS OF NATIVE HAWAIIANS AND HAWAI‘I-BASED MUSEUMS. PARTICIPANTS IN THE PROGRAM WILL DEVELOP KNOWLEDGE, SKILLS, AND CAPACITY IN THE WORK THEY DO, ENABLING THEM TO STRENGTHEN PROGRAMS AND INCREASE SUPPORT FOR THE COMMUNITIES THEY SERVE.

KAW NATION’S KANZA MUSEUM WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTION BY IMPLEMENTING A COLLECTIONS INVENTORY AND CATALOGING PROJECT TO PRESERVE AND PROTECT KANZA ARTIFACTS, PHOTOS, GLASS SIDES, AND OTHER ITEMS OF CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE HIRING AND MENTORING A NEW COLLECTIONS CARE SPECIALIST WHO WILL INVENTORY THE MUSEUM’S COLLECTION, CREATE AND IMPLEMENT A CATALOG SYSTEM, AND PROCURE ARCHIVAL QUALITY MATERIALS TO REHOUSE AND STORE ITEMS. AS A RESULT, THE TRIBE WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO SAFEGUARD AND PRESERVE THE ITEMS AND THEIR RELATED HISTORICAL INFORMATION ON THE KANZA PEOPLE FOR FUTURE REFERENCE, EXHIBITION, AND USE BY MUSEUM STAFF, TRIBAL MEMBERS, AND THE COMMUNITY.

KONIAG, INC. WILL DESIGN AND PUBLISH A BOOK THAT CELEBRATES THE LIVING ARTISTIC TRADITIONS OF THE KODIAK ALUTIIQ PEOPLE BY SHARING THE CONTEMPORARY NATIVE ART COLLECTIONS OF TWO COMMUNITY MUSEUMS – THE ALUTIIQ MUSEUM AND THE KODIAK HISTORY MUSEUM. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL IDENTIFY ARTISTS AND ARTWORKS FOR INCLUSION IN THE BOOK, PHOTOGRAPH AND PROCESS IMAGES, OBTAIN USE PERMISSIONS, RESEARCH AND WRITE ARTIST BIOGRAPHIES AND SHORT ESSAYS, AND DESIGN THE LAYOUT. UPON PUBLICATION, 1000 COPIES WILL BE PRINTED AND DISTRIBUTED FOR FREE THROUGHOUT THE COMMUNITY AND A DIGITAL COPY WILL BE SHARED ON THE ALUTIIQ MUSEUM’S WEBSITE. THE RESULTING BOOK WILL ILLUSTRATE THE RICH ARTISTIC TRADITIONS OF ALUTIIQ HISTORY, CULTURE, AND EXPERIENCE, WHILE SUPPORTING NATIVE ARTISTS, INCREASING PUBLIC AWARENESS OF CONTEMPORARY NATIVE ARTS, AND ENHANCING THE DOCUMENTATION OF THESE COLLECTIONS.

ELK VALLEY RANCHERIA WILL IMPROVE THE CARE, MANAGEMENT, AND LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF ITS COLLECTION OF ETHNOGRAPHIC ITEMS, LITHICS AND STONE TOOLS, DOCUMENTS, AND BOOKS. DRAWING ON RECOMMENDATIONS FROM A 2015 CONSERVATION SURVEY AND ASSESSMENT, THE TRIBE WILL PURCHASE AND INSTALL MUSEUM-QUALITY DISPLAY CASES THAT PROTECT THE COLLECTIONS FROM CHANGES IN TEMPERATURE, RELATIVE HUMIDITY, AND ULTRAVIOLET LIGHT. HOUSING THE TRIBE’S CULTURAL MATERIALS, WHICH INCLUDE OVER 100 HISTORICAL BASKETS, IN NEW CASES WILL PRESERVE THEM FOR FUTURE GENERATIONS AND ENABLE BOTH NATIVE AND NON-NATIVE MEMBERS OF THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY TO CONTINUE TO VISIT AND LEARN ABOUT THE LIFEWAYS, VALUES, AND HISTORY OF ELK VALLEY RANCHERIA.

THE CITIZEN POTAWATOMI NATION CULTURAL HERITAGE CENTER WILL CREATE TEN OUTDOOR EDUCATIONAL DISPLAYS AT SITES OF HISTORICAL OR CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE AROUND THE NATION’S PUBLIC GROUNDS. THE SIGNAGE WILL BE EQUIPPED WITH QR CODES TO ACCESS A SELF-DIRECTED ALTERNATE REALITY (AR) CONTENT DELIVERY PLATFORM, PROVIDING INFORMATION ON POTAWATOMI HISTORY AND CULTURE VIA VISITORS’ PERSONAL DEVICES. THIS PROJECT WILL SUPPORT DESIGNING, PRINTING, AND INSTALLING THE TEN DISPLAYS, AS WELL AS PRODUCING 2D AND 3D CONTENT FOR USE IN THE AR PLATFORM. AS A RESULT OF THE NEW DISPLAYS, POTAWATOMI TRIBAL MEMBERS, OTHER NATIVE AMERICAN COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL INCREASE THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF POTAWATOMI ORIGINS, HISTORY, AND CULTURE.

THE OTOE MISSOURIA TRIBE WILL COORDINATE AN IN-PERSON MEETING OF TRIBAL LEADERS AND CULTURAL REPRESENTATIVES TO SUPPORT TRIBAL PARTICIPATION IN A PILOT PROGRAM FOCUSED ON INTERNATIONAL REPATRIATION OF NATIVE AMERICAN ANCESTORS AND CULTURAL ITEMS. THE PROGRAM WILL BRING LEADERS FROM MULTIPLE INTERNATIONAL MUSEUMS TO OKLAHOMA FOR A MULTI-DAY MEETING WITH THE GOAL OF EXCHANGING IDEAS, PROMOTING CONSTRUCTIVE DIALOGUE, AND DEVELOPING POSITIVE RELATIONSHIPS. THE LONG-TERM GOAL IS TO FACILITATE THE RETURN OF NATIVE AMERICAN HERITAGE ITEMS HELD IN FOREIGN MUSEUM COLLECTIONS. BENEFITTING FROM THIS EFFORT WILL BE THE PARTICIPATING TRIBAL NATIONS AND INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS, AS THEY FOSTER GREATER CROSS-CULTURAL UNDERSTANDING AND SHARE LESSONS LEARNED TO HELP GUIDE FUTURE EXCHANGES AND DIALOGUE.

THE BAD RIVER BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR TRIBE OF CHIPPEWA INDIANS WILL INITIATE OPERATIONS AND COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PROCEDURES TO SUPPORT THE OPENING OF ITS NEW MOKA'AANGIIZIS (“RISING SUN”) TRIBAL MUSEUM. THE TRIBE WILL HIRE A MUSEUM MANAGER WHO WILL LEAD THE MUSEUM THROUGH ITS GRAND OPENING, DEVELOP INITIAL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES, AND ESTABLISH A VOLUNTEER VISITOR SERVICES PROGRAM. ADDITIONAL PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COLLECTIONS DATABASE AND THE PRODUCTION OF VIRTUAL MUSEUM RESOURCES, SUCH AS WEBSITE UPDATES, AN ONLINE NEWSLETTER, AND A VIRTUAL EXHIBIT. COUPLING THESE EFFORTS WITH ONGOING LONG-RANGE PLANNING WILL BUILD AND SUSTAIN PROFESSIONAL MUSEUM ACTIVITIES AND HELP ESTABLISH THE MUSEUM AS A VIBRANT CULTURAL CENTER FOR THE BAD RIVER BAND TRIBAL COMMUNITY AND BEYOND.

THE KAHOʻOLAWE ISLAND RESERVE COMMISSION (KIRC), UNDER THE HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF LAND AND NATURAL RESOURCES, WILL ADVANCE STEWARDSHIP AND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS, WHICH INCLUDE NATURAL, CULTURAL, HISTORICAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND ARCHEOLOGICAL RESOURCES. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE UPGRADING HARDLINE SERVICES AND TECHNICAL HARDWARE TO A CLOUD-BASED SYSTEM AND INCREASING ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY BY PROVIDING STAFF WITH THE ABILITY TO WORK BOTH ON-SITE AND REMOTELY FROM THREE DIFFERENT ISLANDS. THE UPGRADES WILL ENABLE THE KIRC TO OFFER INCREASED ACCESS TO DIGITAL RESOURCES, SUCH AS THE LIVING LIBRARY PLATFORM AND DATABASE, THE KAHOʻOLAWE ISLAND GUIDE APP, LIVE-STREAMING VIDEO, AND A KAHOʻOLAWE VIRTUAL REALITY HUAKAʻI. AS A RESULT, LOCAL AND NATIVE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITIES AS WELL AS THE GENERAL PUBLIC WILL HAVE SAFE AND MEANINGFUL PHYSICAL AND VIRTUAL ENGAGEMENT WITH THE KIRC’S RESOURCES.

THE OJIBWE LEARNING CENTER AND LIBRARY (OLCL) WILL DEVELOP AN ARTS PROGRAM TO IDENTIFY AND SUPPORT ANISHINAABE ART AND ARTISTS TO STRENGTHEN THEIR ABILITY TO BUILD, MAINTAIN, AND PRESERVE CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE CONDUCTING AN ARTS NEEDS ASSESSMENT SURVEY, ESTABLISHING AN ARTS ADVISORY GROUP, AND DEVELOPING ART WORKSHOP PROGRAMMING. THE PROGRAM WILL PROVIDE UNDER-SERVED AND UNDER-RECOGNIZED ANISHINAABE ARTISTS WITH PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES, HELP BUILD THEIR SKILLS WHILE DEVELOPING AVENUES FOR FINANCIAL SUPPORT, CONNECT MENTORS AND MENTEES, AND ENCOURAGE THE EMERGENCE OF A NEW GENERATION OF ANISHINAABE ARTISTS. AS A RESULT, THE OLCL WILL FURTHER ITS MISSION TO EDUCATE THE COMMUNITY ABOUT THEIR CULTURE, SUPPORT CULTURAL PRESERVATION EFFORTS, AND PROVIDE A PLATFORM FOR REMATRIATING CULTURAL AND ARTISTIC PRACTICES.

THE BUENA VISTA RANCHERIA OF ME-WUK INDIANS WILL ORGANIZE THE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS HOUSED AT THE UPUSANI CULTURAL CENTER TO AID IN THE CURATION AND EXHIBITION OF COLLECTIONS. THEY WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS SPECIALIST TO HELP PROCESS, CATALOG, AND PRESERVE THE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTION UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE TRIBAL HISTORIC PRESERVATION OFFICER AND AN ADVISORY BOARD. THE TRIBE WILL HOLD PROGRAMMATIC EVENTS ASSOCIATED WITH THE COLLECTION THROUGHOUT THE DURATION OF THE PROJECT FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS, GUESTS, AND THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY. THE PROJECT WILL ESTABLISH THE ARCHEOLOGICAL COLLECTION AS A RESOURCE IN BOTH PHYSICAL AND DIGITAL FORMATS, AND RESULT IN THE PROTECTION AND ADVANCEMENT OF TRIBAL HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE AND CULTURAL PRACTICES.

NINILCHIK VILLAGE WILL IMPLEMENT A PLANNING PROJECT THAT SUPPORTS THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE TRIBE’S NEW CULTURAL INSTITUTION, THE Q’ESCHIŁ HERITAGE CENTER. ESTABLISHING A TRIBALLY OWNED AND OPERATED MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER WILL ENABLE NINILCHIK VILLAGE TO MAINTAIN AND MANAGE ITS OWN VOICE TO EDUCATE AND COMMUNICATE ITS HISTORY, CULTURE, AND IDENTITY TO THE COMMUNITIES OF THE LOWER KENAI PENINSULA REGION AND BEYOND. PROJECT FUNDS WILL SUPPORT STAFF AS THEY DEVELOP POLICY AND GOVERNANCE STRUCTURE PLANS, LAUNCH HERITAGE OUTREACH EFFORTS, AND FINALIZE EXHIBIT DESIGN PLANS IN PREPARATION FOR THE CULTURAL CENTER'S CONSTRUCTION.

THE TWENTY-NINE PALMS BAND OF MISSION INDIANS WILL CONTINUE AN ONGOING PROJECT TO DEVELOP A CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM THAT WILL SERVE AS A PLACE WHERE ITS MEMBERS CAN COME TOGETHER TO PRACTICE, CELEBRATE, AND PASS ON THEIR CULTURAL HERITAGE. THE TRIBE WILL SELECT AND HIRE A CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP A FINANCIAL PLAN THAT WILL GUIDE MUSEUM OPERATIONS AND INTEGRATE ITS MISSION, VISION, AND VALUES WITH SHORT- AND LONG-TERM FINANCIAL PLANNING, FUNDRAISING, AND MARKETING. PLANNING FOR STABLE FISCAL MANAGEMENT FOR THE MUSEUM WILL ENABLE MUSEUM LEADERS TO LEVERAGE RESOURCES AND MAKE DECISIONS WITH GREATER CONFIDENCE. THE FUTURE MUSEUM WILL SERVE TRIBAL AND LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHILE PRESERVING THE CULTURAL LEGACY, LIVING TRADITIONS, KNOWLEDGE, AND LANGUAGE THAT MAKE UP CHEMEHUEVI CULTURE.

THE WIYOT TRIBE WILL DEVELOP MAPS OF THE PLACE NAMES OF ANCESTRAL TERRITORY IN THE NATIVE WIYOT LANGUAGE OF SOULATLUK. UTILIZING MAPPING AND ANALYTICS SOFTWARE, A PUBLIC-FACING MAP WILL CONTAIN PLACE NAMES AND LOCATIONS THAT ARE NOT CULTURALLY SENSITIVE, WHILE A SEPARATE TRIBAL-USE VERSION WILL CONTAIN ALL DOCUMENTED PLACE NAMES. FOCUSED ARCHIVAL AND FIELD RESEARCH TO RECOVER THESE PLACE NAMES AND ACCURATELY LOCATE THEM WITHIN ANCESTRAL LANDS WILL RESULT IN PUBLISHED BROCHURES AND LARGE FORMAT PRINTED MAPS FOR EXHIBITION. THE MAPS WILL SERVE AS AN ONGOING RESOURCE FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS TO RECLAIM AND CARE FOR THEIR LANGUAGE AND ANCESTRAL LANDS AS WELL AS FOR RESIDENTS OF THE ANCESTRAL WIYOT TERRITORY TO LEARN ABOUT WIYOT LAND STEWARDSHIP, CULTURE, AND THE SOULATLUK LANGUAGE.

PAPAHANA KUAOLA WILL PROVIDE PROGRAMMATIC OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO LEARN ABOUT THE TRADITIONS OF LAUHALA WEAVING AND SUPPORT THE ART AS A HAWAIIAN LIFESTYLE PRACTICE. THROUGH WORKSHOPS AND DEMONSTRATIONS WITH CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS, PARTICIPATING SCHOOL GROUPS, ADULTS, AND FAMILIES WILL ENGAGE WITH HALA HISTORY AND TRADITIONS, DEVELOP WEAVING SKILLS, AND CREATE A LINK TO THEIR PAST AND FUTURE GENERATIONS BY PERPETUATING HAWAIIAN TRADITIONS. THE PROJECT WILL CULMINATE WITH A CELEBRATORY EVENT WHERE CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS WILL SHOWCASE THEIR LAUHALA MANAO. A PROJECT WEBPAGE INCLUDING INTERVIEWS WITH CONTEMPORARY PRACTITIONERS AND ARCHIVAL FOOTAGE WILL SERVE AS A CONTINUOUS RESOURCE OF DOCUMENTED LAUHALA-RELATED ARTIFACTS AND EXPERIENCES.

THE AH-TAH-THI-KI MUSEUM OF THE SEMINOLE TRIBE OF FLORIDA WILL RESEARCH AND DIGITALLY CATALOG A COLLECTION OF HISTORIC NEWSPAPERS FROM THE 18TH AND 19TH CENTURIES. BUILDING ON AN EARLIER GRANT AWARD TO IMPROVE CATALOG RECORDS AND CREATE A FINDING AID, THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A RESEARCH ASSISTANT TO SCAN AND GENERATE HIGH-RESOLUTION, SEARCHABLE IMAGES FOR HUNDREDS OF NEWSPAPERS, WHICH WILL THEN BE MADE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE TO NATIVE AND WORLDWIDE RESEARCH COMMUNITIES AS A ROBUST DIGITAL ARCHIVE. THE UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH FLORIDA ACCESS 3D LAB WILL PROVIDE TECHNICAL TRAINING AND ACCESS TO THE EQUIPMENT NECESSARY TO COMPLETE THE PROJECT. A MUSEUM NEWSLETTER WILL SHARE PROJECT UPDATES AND RESULTS RELATED TO THE PRESERVATION AND ACCESS OF THIS HISTORIC MATERIAL.

THE POEH CULTURAL CENTER WILL REDESIGN AND REORGANIZE THEIR COLLECTIONS STORAGE SPACE FOR WORKS CREATED BY CONTEMPORARY AND HISTORIC TEWA ARTISTS IN THE SOUTHWEST. THE CENTER WILL HIRE INTERNS FROM THE INSTITUTE OF AMERICAN INDIAN ARTS, A COLLECTIONS REGISTRAR, AND CONSULTANTS TO CONDUCT AN INVENTORY AND INPUT INFORMATION INTO A CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. STAFF WILL COMPLETE DETAILED CONDITION REPORTS FOR OBJECTS BOTH ON AND OFF-SITE. THE IMPROVEMENTS WILL RESULT IN MORE EFFECTIVE COLLECTIONS CARE AND EXHIBITION PLANNING, WHILE TEWA COMMUNITY MEMBERS AS WELL AS ARTISTS AND SCHOLARS WILL HAVE INCREASED ACCESS TO THE COLLECTIONS.

THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE WILL CONDUCT A COMPREHENSIVE FEASIBILITY STUDY IN ORDER TO GAIN AN UNDERSTANDING OF POTENTIAL OPTIONS FOR UTILIZING A NEWLY ACQUIRED PROPERTY AS THE FUTURE SITE OF THE TRIBE’S FIRST MUSEUM AND CULTURAL CENTER. THE AM’SAÁXPA (“PLACE OF BOULDERS”) PROPERTY, LOCATED IN THE HEART OF THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE’S TRADITIONAL HOMELAND, IS A HISTORIC PROPERTY IN JOSEPH, OREGON, FORMERLY A NEZ PERCE TRIBAL VILLAGE SITE OCCUPIED BY CHIEF JOSEPH, WHO IS BURIED NEARBY. ADDITIONAL PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE PURCHASING EXHIBIT CASES AND DEVELOPING A TEMPORARY EXHIBIT OF REPLICA ARTIFACTS, WHICH WILL INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF THE TRIBE TO SERVE ITS MEMBERS, THE LOCAL PUBLIC, AND ALL THOSE INTERESTED IN LEARNING ABOUT THE NEZ PERCE PEOPLE.

THE DELAWARE NATION WILL PARTNER WITH THE 3D SCANNING LAB AT THE UNIVERSITY OF OKLAHOMA LIBRARIES TO PRODUCE HIGH-QUALITY, HIGH-RESOLUTION 3D MODELS OF THE NATION’S ARCHIVAL AND MUSEUM ARTIFACTS. A CLOUD-BASED STORAGE SYSTEM AND DIGITAL CATALOG WILL PROVIDE CITIZENS AND RESEARCHERS ONLINE ACCESS TO THE IMAGES OF THE 3D MODELS, WHICH WILL ALSO BE DISPLAYED ON-SITE FOR VISITORS TO THE DELAWARE NATION LIBRARY. THE DIGITIZATION OF ARTIFACTS WILL PROVIDE BROADER ACCESS TO INFORMATION ABOUT THE COLLECTION AND THE CULTURAL HISTORY OF THE LENAPE PEOPLE, AND WILL SERVE AS THE FOUNDATION FOR A FUTURE, FULLY INTERACTIVE ONLINE MUSEUM.

THE PEORIA TRIBE OF INDIANS OF OKLAHOMA WILL DESIGN AND FABRICATE AN EXHIBIT FOR DISPLAY AT THE DICKSON MOUNDS MUSEUM IN LEWISTOWN, ILLINOIS, TO TELL THE STORY OF THE EMIQUON PRESERVE AND ITS SIGNIFICANCE TO THE TRIBE. SCENES DEPICTING THE EVOLUTION OF THE PRESERVE FROM A NATURAL WETLAND THAT SUPPORTED GENERATIONS OF TRIBAL ANCESTORS WITHIN THEIR ORIGINAL HOMELANDS, TO BEING DRAINED AND TURNED INTO FARMLAND, TO ITS EVENTUAL REBIRTH AS AN INTERNATIONALLY SIGNIFICANT PROTECTED WETLAND, WILL ENABLE THE TRIBE TO SHOWCASE THEIR HERITAGE IN THEIR OWN WORDS. THE RESULTING EXHIBIT WILL INVITE LOCAL RESIDENTS AND VISITORS FROM ACROSS THE NATION TO VIEW AND EXPERIENCE THE EMIQUON PRESERVE WITH A DEEPER UNDERSTANDING OF THE CULTURAL SIGNIFICANCE, BEAUTY, AND RESOURCEFULNESS OF THE AREA.

THE SEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTE WILL ENHANCE DIGITAL PRESERVATION PRACTICES AND EXPAND DIGITAL STORAGE CAPACITY TO INCREASE ACCESS TO THEIR INDIGENOUS ARCHIVES. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND TRAINING FOR STAFF TO GAIN EXPERTISE IN DIGITAL ARCHIVES MANAGEMENT. STAFF WILL ALSO ESTABLISH A FORMAL, COMPREHENSIVE DIGITAL PRESERVATION MANAGEMENT POLICY TO SUPPORT THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF DIGITIZED AND BORN-DIGITAL ARCHIVAL HOLDINGS, INCLUDING THEIR AUDIO COLLECTION OF TLINGIT, HAIDA, AND TSIMSHIAN ORAL TRADITIONS. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN INCREASED ACCESS TO ARCHIVAL RECORDS FOR RESEARCH AND EDUCATIONAL PURPOSES FOR INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC IN SOUTHEAST ALASKA AND BEYOND.

KONIAG, INC. WILL DEVELOP A COMPREHENSIVE, COMMUNITY-INFORMED PLAN FOR A NEW SET OF ALUTIIQ HERITAGE EXHIBITS FOR THEIR MUSEUM, THE ALUTIIQ MUSEUM & ARCHAEOLOGICAL REPOSITORY. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE WORKING WITH AN ALASKAN EXHIBIT DESIGNER TO ENGAGE COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN EXHIBIT CONCEPTUALIZATION; CREATE A SCHEMATIC DESIGN TIED TO AN EXHIBIT STYLE GUIDE; DEVELOP A DRAFT SCRIPT WITH OBJECTS, PHOTOS, AND ALUTIIQ VOCABULARY; CREATE A DE-INSTALLATION PLAN FOR THE CURRENT EXHIBITS; DRAFT A BUDGET FOR DESIGN AND FABRICATION; AND MENTOR STAFF IN EXHIBIT DEVELOPMENT. THE PROCESS TO DEVELOP THE COMMUNITY-INFORMED EXHIBIT PLAN WILL HELP THE MUSEUM STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS WITH, AND BETTER UNDERSTAND THE NEEDS OF, ITS NATIVE COMMUNITY.

THE KANZA MUSEUM AND THE KANZA LIBRARY AND LEARNING CENTER WILL PROVIDE A SERIES OF PROGRAMS FOCUSED ON INCREASING NATIVE COMMUNITY INVOLVEMENT THROUGH THE TEACHING OF TRADITIONAL ARTS AND CRAFTS. A TRIBAL ELDER WILL TEACH CULTURAL HISTORY TO PARTICIPANTS, AS WELL AS TRADITIONAL METHODS OF MAKING TRIBAL ITEMS AND REGALIA, INCLUDING MOCCASINS, FRINGE SHAWLS, JEWELRY, RIBBON SKIRTS, AND SHIRTS. THEY WILL INFUSE THE PROGRAMS WITH KAÁⁿZE ÍE, THE KAW LANGUAGE, AND DISPLAY CRAFTED ITEMS MADE BY PARTICIPANTS AT FASHION SHOWS AND CULTURAL EVENTS. PARTICIPATING KAW TRIBAL CITIZENS AND INTERESTED NON-NATIVE COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL LEARN TRIBAL LANGUAGE, HISTORY, AND CULTURE, INCREASING A SENSE OF TRIBAL COMMUNITY AND PRIDE, AND HELPING PRESERVE TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE.

THE INSTITUTE FOR NATIVE PACIFIC EDUCATION AND CULTURE (INPEACE) WILL DESIGN THE LOKO IʻA TRAVELING EXHIBIT, AN INDIGENOUS STEM EXPERIENCE. LOKO LʻA ARE TRADITIONAL FISHPONDS, A CENTRAL NATIVE HAWAIIAN LAND MANAGEMENT PRACTICE, AND THE EXHIBIT WILL INCORPORATE INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES WHILE UTILIZING OBSERVATIONAL, PROBLEM-SOLVING, AND HAND-ON APPROACHES DESIGNED TO ENGAGE YOUTH AND FAMILIES IN THEIR OWN COMMUNITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE COLLECTING INFORMATION FROM CULTURAL EXPERTS, RESEARCHERS, AND KUPUNA; COMPILING INFORMATION INTO A DESIGN REFERENCE GUIDE; DEVELOPING CONCEPTUAL PLANS WITH COMMUNITY AND DESIGN EXPERTS; COMPLETING AND REFINING EXHIBIT LAYOUTS, SPECIFICATIONS, AND MATERIALS; AND SECURING COST ESTIMATES FOR FABRICATION AND BUILDOUT. THE RESULTING DESIGNS WILL REFLECT A CULTURE-BASED STEM EXHIBIT THAT PROVIDES NATIVE HAWAIIANS THE OPPORTUNITY TO VIEW THE WORLD AND THEIR ENVIRONMENT THROUGH A LENS THAT IS RELEVANT TO THEIR LIVES.

THE SAN CARLOS APACHE TRIBE WILL DEVELOP AND OFFER PROGRAMMING TO REINTRODUCE TRADITIONAL APACHE GAMES TO TRIBAL YOUTH AND FAMILIES. MEETINGS AND WORKSHOPS CONDUCTED WITH APACHE ELDERS AND TRADITIONAL PRACTITIONERS WILL ENABLE PROGRAM PARTICIPANTS TO MAKE THE NECESSARY OBJECTS AND INSTRUMENTS FOR THE GAMES, LEARN APACHE VOCABULARY, HARVEST TRADITIONAL PLANTS AND FOODS, AND ENGAGE IN SEASONAL CEREMONIES FOR WELLNESS AND RENEWAL. THE PROJECT WILL CULMINATE IN AN “APACHE OLYMPICS,” IN WHICH ALL APACHE TRIBES IN ARIZONA AND NEW MEXICO ARE INVITED TO PARTICIPATE, HELPING TO REVITALIZE AND SUSTAIN TRADITIONAL GAMES THAT HAVE NOT BEEN PLAYED SINCE THE LATE 1950S. THE SAN CARLOS APACHE CULTURE CENTER MUSEUM WILL STORE AND DISPLAY THE CRAFTED OBJECTS USED IN THE GAMES, AS WELL AS CREATE REFERENCE BOOKLETS AND RECORD SONGS AND STORIES AS ANOTHER SOURCE OF KNOWLEDGE FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS FOR FUTURE USE.

KAʻALA FARM WILL TRANSFORM ITSELF INTO A “LIVING MUSEUM” BY PRESERVING ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES LOCATED ON THE KAʻALA LEARNING CENTER’S PROPERTY AND BY REFRAMING AND DEEPENING THE HISTORICAL NARRATIVE TO INCLUDE THE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITY PERSPECTIVE FOR BOTH LOCAL AND NON-LOCAL VISITORS. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE RESEARCHING AND DEVELOPING TOURS OF OUTDOOR TRAILS AND ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES, RECRUITING AND TRAINING COMMUNITY MEMBER DOCENTS, AND IMPLEMENTING TAILORED TOURS FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND NON-COMMUNITY VISITORS. BY EXPANDING OPPORTUNITIES FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO TELL THEIR OWN STORIES AND PROPERLY PRESERVING ARCHEOLOGICAL SITES, KAʻALA FARM WILL TEACH VISITORS A MORE COMPLETE HISTORY OF THE WAIʻANAE REGION AND HELP DEVELOP A COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGEABLE ABOUT THEIR OWN HISTORY.

THE BAY MILLS INDIAN COMMUNITY WILL EXPAND THE POINT IROQUOIS LIGHTHOUSE MUSEUM TO PROTECT, PRESERVE, AND PERPETUATE THE ANISHINAABE STORY, LANGUAGE, AND CULTURAL PRACTICES. BUILDING ON A MUSEUM ASSESSMENT PROGRAM (MAP) REPORT, THE TRIBE WILL CONDUCT A SECURITY ASSESSMENT OF THE FACILITY TO ENSURE PROPER MANAGEMENT OF THE HISTORIC PROPERTY AND HIRE A CURATOR TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROCEDURES. TO MORE FULLY ENGAGE VISITORS, INCLUDING TRIBAL MEMBERS, STUDENTS, AND THE GENERAL PUBLIC, THE CURATOR WILL DEVELOP A CALENDAR OF EVENTS AND A REGISTRY OF TRIBAL ARTISTS, STORYTELLERS, EDUCATORS, AND HISTORIANS TO PROVIDE APPROPRIATE AND HISTORICALLY ACCURATE PROGRAMMING.

THE ILANKA CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM OF THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF EYAK WILL CREATE HIGH-DEFINITION 3D SCANS OF 15 ARTIFACTS HELD IN THE ILANKA MUSEUM AND CORDOVA MUSEUM COLLECTIONS. BUILDING UPON A PREVIOUS PROJECT TO CREATE A VIRTUAL REALITY EXPERIENCE OF A TRADITIONAL VILLAGE SITE, THESE ARTIFACTS WILL ENABLE USERS TO PERFORM ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS CANOEING, DRUMMING, TRACKING, AND GAMEPLAY. TRIBAL ELDERS WILL CONTRIBUTE KNOWLEDGE OF TRADITIONAL OBJECT USE AND SERVE AS STORYTELLERS WITHIN THE VIRTUAL REALITY EXPERIENCE. THIS PRESERVATION PROJECT WILL RESULT IN AN IMMERSIVE, SHORT STORY EXPERIENCE OF CULTURAL ACTIVITIES FOR VISITORS, TRIBAL MEMBERS, AND YOUTH PARTICIPANTS.

THE YAVAPAI-APACHE NATION CULTURAL CENTER WILL STRENGTHEN ITS SERVICES BY IMPLEMENTING IMPROVEMENTS IN COLLECTIONS CARE AND PROGRAMMING. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE AN EVALUATION OF THE CENTER’S CLIMATE CONTROL SYSTEM TO ENSURE THE LONG-TERM PRESERVATION OF COLLECTION ITEMS IN STORAGE AND ON DISPLAY. STAFF WILL UPGRADE SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT ONGOING LANGUAGE PRESERVATION AND ORAL HISTORY PROGRAMMING. TRIBAL MEMBERS WILL ALSO TRAVEL TO FIVE DIFFERENT LOCATIONS AROUND THE COUNTRY TO RESEARCH, IDENTIFY, AND EXAMINE ITEMS THAT HAVE THE POTENTIAL FOR REPATRIATION AND CARE BY THE NATION. REPAIRS TO THE CENTER’S POTTERY WHEEL WILL SUPPORT ITS USE FOR DEMONSTRATIONS, CLASSES, AND POTTERY MAKING. VISITORS, INCLUDING TRIBAL MEMBERS, THE LOCAL VERDE VALLEY COMMUNITY, AND NON-LOCAL TOURISTS, WILL BENEFIT FROM INCREASED ACCESS TO THE NATION’S PRESERVED HISTORICAL AND CULTURAL MATERIALS.

THREE CHIEFS CULTURE CENTER OF THE CONFEDERATED SALISH AND KOOTENAI TRIBES WILL RESTORE AND REHOUSE ARTIFACTS DAMAGED BY AN ARSON FIRE IN 2020. THE PROJECT WILL FUND OBJECT CONSERVATION, ENVIRONMENTAL IMPROVEMENTS, AND FIRESAFE STORAGE FOR THE COLLECTION. A CONSERVATOR AND AN APPRAISER WILL ASSIST STAFF IN THE RESTORATION AND PRESERVATION OF DAMAGED CULTURAL RESOURCES OF THE BITTERROOT SALISH, UPPER PEND D’OREILLE, AND KOOTENAI PEOPLE. STAFF WILL UPDATE THE COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT POLICY, PARTICIPATE IN DATABASE TRAINING, DIGITIZE RECORDS AND COLLECTION MATERIALS, TRANSFER VIDEO AND DIGITAL MEDIA, CONDUCT APPRAISALS, AND COMPLETE THE CATALOGING OF RECORDS. THIS PROJECT WILL ENHANCE THE TRIBE’S ABILITY TO CARE FOR ITS COLLECTIONS, BENEFITTING BOTH TRIBAL AND NON-TRIBAL COMMUNITIES.

THE CITIZEN POTAWATOMI NATION WILL MODERNIZE AND ENHANCE EXHIBIT-BASED TECHNOLOGY TO IMPROVE THE VISITOR EXPERIENCE AT ITS CULTURAL HERITAGE CENTER. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE UPDATING TOUCH SCREEN INTERFACES, SPEAKERS, AND COMPUTERS THAT DELIVER CONTENT TO GALLERY SCREENS. IN ADDITION, THE CITIZEN POTAWATOMI NATION WILL REVITALIZE EXHIBIT NARRATIVES BY CHANGING THE STRUCTURE OF INTERACTIVE CONTENT FROM STATIC LOOPS TO VISITOR-SELECTED TOPICS TO PROVIDE AN UPDATED EXPERIENCE. THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO CREATE A GALLERY SPACE THAT IS MORE VISITOR-DIRECTED AND RESPONSIVE FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS, MEMBERS OF OTHER TRIBES, AND VISITORS FROM THE SURROUNDING NON-NATIVE COMMUNITY.

THE BISHOP PAIUTE TRIBE WILL CREATE A CULTURAL OUTREACH AND EDUCATION PROGRAM AT ITS OWENS VALLEY PAIUTE SHOSHONE CULTURAL CENTER. ALIGNED WITH THE TRIBE'S STRATEGIC PLAN, THE GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO PRESERVE, STRENGTHEN, AND RENEW CULTURAL CONNECTION THROUGH EDUCATION PROGRAMS AS THEY RELATE TO THE NATURAL RESOURCES OF TRIBAL LANDS ON AND OFF TRIBAL RESERVATIONS. A NEWLY CREATED POSITION OF CULTURAL OUTREACH COORDINATOR WILL FACILITATE THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN INTRODUCTORY PROGRAM--'EASTERN SIERRA WATERSHEDS: THE CULTURALLY HISTORIC CONNECTION BETWEEN WATER AND THE PAIUTE AND SHOSHONE PEOPLE.' THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ORGANIZE FIELD TRIPS TO WATERSHEDS AND CONDUCT RESEARCH TO DEVELOP WATER SHED CURRICULUM KITS, TEN OF WHICH WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO LOCAL PARTNERS, TRIBES AND AVAILABLE FOR CHECK-OUT FROM THE MUSEUM. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO PRODUCE A FIVE-PANEL EXHIBIT TO BE PERMANENTLY DISPLAYED IN THE CENTER.

HI'IPAKA, LLC WILL ENHANCE ITS EFFORTS TO SUSTAIN HAWAIIAN HERITAGE, CULTURE, AND COMMUNITY KNOWLEDGE BY BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF STAFF TO ADOPT BEST PRACTICES AND INNOVATIONS TO BETTER CARE FOR AND INTERPRET THE COLLECTIONS OF WAIMEA VALLEY. A CONSULTING CONSERVATOR WILL COMPLETE A GENERAL CONSERVATION SURVEY OF THE COLLECTIONS, WHICH INCLUDE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL SITES, NATIVE HAWAIIAN PLANT COLLECTIONS, AND NATIVE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL ARTIFACTS. THE PROJECT INCLUDES FUNDS TO PURCHASE NECESSARY SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT STAFF WORK UNDER THE GUIDANCE OF THE CONSERVATOR TO ASSESS, CATALOG, REHOUSE COLLECTIONS, AND IMPROVE ONGOING COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT PRACTICES. THE LONGER-TERM PROJECT GOAL IS TO IMPROVE THE WELLBEING OF THE SURROUNDING COMMUNITY BY SERVING AS A TRUSTED SPACE FOR COMMUNITY DIALOGUE AND THE CARE AND INTERPRETATION OF HAWAIIAN CULTURE.

BUILDING ON COMPLETED STRATEGIC AND ARCHITECTURAL PLANS FOR A TRIBAL CULTURAL CENTER/MUSEUM, THE TWENTY-NINE PALMS BAND OF MISSION INDIANS WILL CREATE AN EXHIBIT PLAN AS THE NEXT STEP IN ITS EFFORTS TO RETAIN TRADITIONAL CULTURE AND SHARE ITS HISTORY WITH THE LOCAL COMMUNITY AND OTHERS. THE TRIBE WILL WORK WITH A MUSEUM CONSULTING FIRM AND CONDUCT A COMMUNITY SURVEY TO DEVELOP A DRAFT PLAN FOR EXHIBIT CONFIGURATION. THE TRIBE WILL ALSO ESTABLISH COOPERATIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITH A VARIETY OF PARTNERS TO RECEIVE SHARED CONTENT, EXHIBITS, OR ARTIFACTS WHICH WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE CULTURAL CENTER/MUSEUM’S EXHIBITS TO PROVIDE A HOLISTIC VIEW OF THE BREADTH OF CHEMEHUEVI CULTURE. THE PROJECT WILL RESULT IN A COMPREHENSIVE EXHIBIT PLAN AND ASSOCIATED DESIGN BOARDS FEATURING THE CORE CONCEPTS OF THE EXHIBITS AS WELL AS DESIGN ELEMENTS SUCH AS FONTS, MATERIALS, COLOR PALETTE, TEXTURES, AND CULTURAL MOTIFS.

IOLANI PALACE WILL LAUNCH THE NEXT STAGE OF EXHIBIT DEVELOPMENT AS PART OF A COMPREHENSIVE OVERHAUL OF THE MUSEUM'S VISITOR EXPERIENCE. BASED ON COMPLETED INTERPRETIVE AND EXHIBIT DESIGN PLANS, THE NEW EXHIBIT AREA WILL FOCUS ON TEN THEMES FOR OVER 100,000 VISITORS PER YEAR, WITH AN EMPHASIS ON MULTIGENERATIONAL FAMILY GROUPS AND SCHOOL CLASSES. THE MUSEUM WILL ASSEMBLE A TEAM OF EXPERTS, KNOWLEDGE-BEARERS, TEACHERS, AND OTHER MUSEUM PROFESSIONALS TO BUILD THE VOICE, TEXT, AND CONTENT FOR THE EXHIBIT PANELS AND LABELS, WHICH WILL REFLECT HAWAIIAN HISTORY, CULTURE, AND CONTEMPORARY ISSUES. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO ENGAGE WITH LOCAL RESIDENTS, COLLEGE FACULTY AND STUDENTS, MILITARY SERVICE MEMBERS AND THEIR FAMILIES, AND OTHERS TO ENSURE THAT THE PROCESS OPENS AS MANY DOORS AS POSSIBLE TO SERVING THE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITY AS WELL AS BUILDING BETTER UNDERSTANDING OF HAWAIIAN CULTURE FOR VISITORS.

THE HAWAII STATE ARCHIVES WILL IMPROVE THE PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF ITS COLLECTION OF NEGATIVES DOCUMENTING THE HISTORY, HERITAGE, AND CULTURE OF NATIVE HAWAIIANS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DIGITIZE OVER 22,000 FRAGILE AND DETERIORATING 19TH AND EARLY 20TH CENTURY NEGATIVES, MANY OF WHICH HAVE BEEN PULLED FROM PUBLIC ACCESS DUE TO DAMAGE AND SIGNS OF SEVERE DETERIORATION. THE DIGITAL IMAGES WILL LIVE IN A FREELY ACCESSIBLE, CENTRALIZED, BI-LINGUAL (''LELO HAWAI'I'HAWAIIAN LANGUAGE'AND ENGLISH), SEARCHABLE ONLINE PUBLIC ACCESS DATABASE. TWO HAWAIIAN LANGUAGE GRADUATE STUDENT INTERNS WILL ASSIST WITH DIGITIZATION WORK AND TRANSCRIBING DESCRIPTIVE METADATA.

AHA K'NE WILL WORK WITH A CONSULTANT AND THE OFFICE OF HAWAIIAN AFFAIRS TO CREATE A PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE RESOURCE DOCUMENTING THREE DECADES OF REPATRIATION WORK. N' MEA HAWAI'I (HAWAIIAN ANCESTRAL REMAINS, FUNERARY POSSESSIONS, AND CULTURAL ITEMS) ARE SCATTERED THROUGHOUT THE GLOBE BUT MANY DOCUMENTS, PICTURES, DATABASES, EMAILS, LETTERS AND OTHER RESEARCH RELATING TO ITEMS THAT HAVE BEEN RETURNED ARE STORED IN BOXES IN RURAL HILO. A CONSULTING PROJECT DIRECTOR, REPATRIATION SPECIALIST, AND DOCUMENT TECHNICIAN WILL COORDINATE PROJECT ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING THE CREATION OF A SEARCHABLE DIGITAL ARCHIVE AND TWO NEW DATABASES REFLECTING PAST AND ONGOING EFFORTS TO IDENTIFY N' MEA HAWAI'I HELD NATIONALLY AND INTERNATIONALLY. THE TRANSFORMATION OF THESE MATERIALS INTO A DIGITAL REPOSITORY WILL INCREASE AN UNDERSTANDING OF HEALING FROM TRAUMA, IMPROVING THE WELL-BEING OF HAWAIIAN FAMILIES WHILE SHARING NATIVE HAWAIIAN WORLDVIEWS AND CULTURAL PRACTICES WITH OTHERS.

THE YOUNG OF HEART WORKSHOP WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII TO IMPLEMENT A PROJECT TO CREATE BROADER ACCESS TO THE WORK OF NATIVE HAWAIIAN ARTISTS. THE AI PHAKU PROJECT WILL DISPERSE ARTIST EXHIBITIONS ACROSS THREE CAMPUSES AND FIVE VENUES WITHIN THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII SYSTEM, INCLUDING THE JOHN YOUNG MUSEUM OF ART, THE ART GALLERY, AND THE COMMONS GALLERY AT UH MA'NOA AND AT GALLERY 'IOLANI AT WINDWARD COMMUNITY COLLEGE AND KOA GALLERY AT KAPI'OLANI COMMUNITY COLLEGE. THE SERIES OF EXHIBITS WILL BE ACCOMPANIED BY PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND A COMPREHENSIVE PUBLICATION WITH ARCHIVAL IMAGES, HISTORICAL AND NEWLY COMMISSIONED ESSAYS, ARTIST AND ARTWORK INFORMATION AND INSTALLATION IMAGES. THE PROJECT WILL SERVE OVER 27,000 STUDENTS, INCLUDING APPROXIMATELY 5,400 HAWAIIAN STUDENTS AND WILL ALSO BRING OVER A THOUSAND OTHER VISITORS TO THE CAMPUSES.

IN RESPONSE TO THE NEED FOR NEW PRESENTATION PLATFORMS, THE EASTERN SHAWNEE TRIBE OF OKLAHOMA (ESTO) WILL LAUNCH THE COMMUNICATION FOR HEALING DURING COVID-19 PROJECT. THE TRIBE WILL DIGITIZE COLLECTIONS AND ARCHIVAL RESOURCES, PRESERVE ELDERS' STORIES AND INTERVIEWS, AND DEVELOP A VIRTUAL EXHIBIT TO CREATE A LIVING TIMELINE OF EASTERN SHAWNEE HISTORY. THE RESOURCES WILL BE ACCESSIBLE IN THE GEORGE J. CAPTAIN PUBLIC LIBRARY, THE TRIBE'S ONLINE LIBRARY, AND THE EASTERN SHAWNEE TRIBE OF OKLAHOMA MUSEUM. THE EXHIBITS WILL ALSO BE SHARED THROUGH OPEN-SOURCE MEDIA SUCH AS FACEBOOK AND THE TRIBAL WEBSITE. THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN ESTO'S MUSEUM SERVICES BY PROMOTING TECHNOLOGY TO ENHANCE AND SUSTAIN CULTURAL HERITAGE AND ENGAGEMENT. THE EASTERN SHAWNEE TRIBAL COMMUNITY WILL EXPERIENCE A STRONGER CONNECTION TO ITS OWN HISTORY, CULTURE, AND TRADITIONAL LANGUAGE.

THE KA MAKAIWA: STRENGTHENING DIGITAL ACCESS FOR NATIVE HAWAIIAN FUTURES PROJECT WILL DEVELOP AN APPROACH TO PRODUCING ONLINE EXHIBITS AND RELATED PROGRAMMING FOR THE BISHOP MUSEUM. THE PROJECT WILL ADDRESS BARRIERS TO PHYSICAL ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS EXPECTED TO CONTINUE BEYOND THE PANDEMIC BY EXPANDING ACCESS TO INFORMATION BY DEVELOPING A HIGH-QUALITY, THOUGHTFULLY DESIGNED, AND USER-FRIENDLY ONLINE EXHIBIT PLATFORM. THE MUSEUM WILL CAPTURE PHOTOGRAPHS, VIDEO FOOTAGE, AND OTHER CONTENT FROM THE (RE)GENERATIONS: CHALLENGING SCIENTIFIC RACISM IN HAWAII EXHIBITION, WHICH EXPLORES RACISM AND BIAS IN SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH WHILE CELEBRATING NATIVE HAWAIIAN VOICES AND COLLABORATIVE ENDEAVORS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL TEST A BETA VERSION INTERNALLY AND CONDUCT A THOROUGH INTERNAL REVIEW BEFORE LAUNCHING THE ONLINE EXHIBIT PUBLICLY.

WITH A MISSION TO RESTORE, PRESERVE, AND PROVIDE SAFE, MEANINGFUL ACCESS TO THE KAHO'OLAWE ISLAND RESERVE, THE KAHO'OLAWE ISLAND RESERVE COMMISSION (KIRC) WILL IMPLEMENT NEW WAYS FOR THE PUBLIC TO ACCESS THE HISTORICAL, CULTURAL, AND NATURAL RESOURCES OF THE SITE. DUE TO LIMITATIONS ON PHYSICAL ACCESS RELATED TO FUNDING CONSTRAINTS AND COVID-19, KIRC WILL DEVELOP DIGITAL TOOLS TO PROVIDE THE GREATER COMMUNITY WITH ACCESS TO THE RESERVE THROUGH VIRTUAL MEANS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THREE DELIVERABLES: SHARING LIVESTREAMING VIDEO FROM KAHO'OLAWE ON THE KIRC WEBSITE SHARING 360-DEGREE VIDEO UPDATES OF MONTHLY VOLUNTEER ACCESS ACTIVITIES AND DEVELOPING A PILOT KAHO'OLAWE VIRTUAL REALITY HUAKA'I, OR EXPEDITION. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE KIRC IN SERVING AS A MODEL FOR OTHER NATURAL MUSEUM SPACES THAT HOPE TO MAINTAIN OR EXPAND PUBLIC ACCESS BEYOND A PHYSICAL MEANS TO LOCAL AND WORLDWIDE AUDIENCES.

THE FEDERATED INDIANS OF GRATON RANCHERIA WILL CREATE, DESIGN, AND TEST A TRIBAL INTERPRETIVE PLAN TO DEVELOP CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE INFORMATION REGARDING TRIBAL ARTIFACTS. THE INTERPRETIVE PLAN WILL PROVIDE CONSISTENT GUIDELINES FOR VARIOUS ORGANIZATIONS THAT SEEK TO DISPLAY THE TRIBE'S CULTURAL HERITAGE, AS WELL AS FOR THE TRIBE'S OWN USE IN DISPLAYING ARTIFACTS IN THE TRIBAL GOVERNMENTAL BUILDING. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO PRODUCE AN INTERACTIVE, COMPANION ONLINE VIRTUAL EXHIBIT WHICH WILL BE ACCESSIBLE TO ALL 1,400 TRIBAL CITIZENS THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES AND THE WORLD TO FOSTER GREATER APPRECIATION AND KNOWLEDGE ABOUT THEIR CULTURAL HERITAGE. THE TRIBE WILL ENGAGE A CONSULTANT TO ASSIST WITH THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PLAN AND TRIBAL CITIZENS WILL PARTICIPATE DIRECTLY IN THE PLANNING PROCESS.

THE LAC COURTE OREILLES (LCO) MUSEUM AND VISITORS CENTER WILL PARTNER WITH THE LCO OJIBWE COLLEGE TO DEVELOP AND INSTALL EXHIBITS AT THE MUSEUM AND FOUR OTHER LOCATIONS ON THE RESERVATION WITH THE COMMON THEME OF 'IKWE'THE WOMEN OF LCO.' THE EXHIBITS WILL FOCUS ON SEVEN AREAS IN WHICH LCO IKWE HAVE EXCELLED: TRADITIONAL ARTS, PUBLIC MEDIA, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY HEALTH, MILITARY SERVICE, SOCIAL ACTION, AND THOSE WHO RAISED LARGE FAMILIES. PHOTOS AND OTHER DOCUMENTS USED IN THE EXHIBITS WILL COME FROM THE LCO MUSEUM AND THE LCO OJIBWE COLLEGE, IN ADDITION TO SEVERAL HISTORICAL REPOSITORIES IN THE REGION. FIVE TRIBAL ELDERS WILL ASSIST IN GATHERING INFORMATION FROM FAMILIES IN THE COMMUNITY ABOUT PREVIOUS GENERATIONS OF IKWE IN ADDITION TO SERVING AS DOCENTS UPON THE OPENING OF THE EXHIBITS.

SEALASKA CORPORATION WILL CREATE FIVE CULTURALLY RESPONSIVE LESSON PLANS FOR USE BY ELEMENTARY AND MIDDLE SCHOOL STUDENTS IN JUNEAU, ALASKA. THE 200 STUDENTS TO BE SERVED BY THE PROJECT WILL VISIT THE SEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTE WITH THEIR TEACHERS TO PARTICIPATE IN INQUIRY-BASED EDUCATIONAL PROGRAMMING FOCUSED ON THE MUSEUM'S 1982 BIENNIAL CELEBRATION, WHICH REVITALIZED THE TLINGIT, HAIDA, AND TSIMSHIAN CULTURES. THE PROJECT BUILDS ON PREVIOUS GRANT AWARDS FROM IMLS AND NEH TO DIGITIZE AND EDIT FOOTAGE FROM THE CELEBRATION FESTIVAL. THE SEALASKA HERITAGE INSTITUTE WILL DRAW FROM CONTENT IN 24 EDITED VIDEOS OF THE EVENT, AS WELL AS FROM RESOURCES IN ITS ARCHIVES AND COLLECTIONS TO CREATE THE LESSON PLANS. . THE PROJECT TEAM WILL USE PRE AND POST STUDENT AND TEACHER SURVEYS TO WRITE AND DELIVER A PAPER ON THE PROJECT TO THE MUSEUM COMMUNITY.

THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF EYAK'S ILANKA CULTURAL CENTER (ICC) WILL PURCHASE SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT TO CREATE A DIGITAL COLLECTION DOCUMENTING ITS HISTORY AND TRADITIONS. THE PROJECT WILL BEGIN WITH THE CREATION OF A DIGITAL COLLECTION POLICY TO GUIDE THE WORK. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL MEET WITH TRIBAL ELDERS AND THEIR FAMILIES TO ACQUIRE HISTORICAL PHOTOS, WHICH WILL BE SCANNED AND DOCUMENTED WITH RELATED INFORMATION. ACQUIRING THE DIGITIZING EQUIPMENT AND PROVIDING TRAINING FOR THE STAFF WILL ALLOW THE CULTURAL DEPARTMENT TO ACCESS MORE HISTORICAL PHOTOGRAPHS FROM TRIBAL MEMBERS IN FUTURE YEARS.

FORT MCDOWELL YAVAPAI NATION WILL PRODUCE AN INTERPRETIVE PLAN TO GUIDE THE FUTURE DEVELOPMENT OF ITS MUSEUM. THE CURRENT MUSEUM EXHIBITS HAVE BEEN DISPLAYED SINCE 2012 WITH MINIMAL INTERPRETIVE GRAPHICS IN AN 800 SQUARE FOOT AREA OF A FORMER CHURCH BUILDING IN THE HISTORIC CENTER OF THE COMMUNITY. THE INTERPRETIVE PLAN WILL BE BASED ON BROAD COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN THREE FACILITATED MEETINGS USING PARTICIPANT ENGAGEMENT TECHNIQUES. THE MEETINGS WILL BE FACILITATED BY PROFESSIONALS IN THE FIELD OF MUSEUM DEVELOPMENT WHO ALSO HAVE EXPERIENCE WITH TRIBAL NATIONS. THE PLAN WILL PROVIDE A ROAD MAP WITH CLEAR STEPS FOR ONGOING PHASES OF DEVELOPMENT AND WILL DEMONSTRATE THE TRIBE?S COMMITMENT TO DEVELOPING A MUSEUM THAT TELLS THE NATION?S STORY THE WAY THEY WANT IT TO BE TOLD.

PAPAHANA KUAOLA WILL STRENGTHEN THE CONNECTION BETWEEN KANAKA (PEOPLE) AND AINA (LAND, THAT WHICH FEEDS US) BY DEVELOPING AND PRESENTING COMMUNITY-BASED EDUCATION PROGRAMS FOCUSING ON THE KNOWLEDGE, USE, AND GROWTH OF HAWAIIAN FOOD AND MEDICINAL PLANTS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT NINE SEQUENTIAL LEARNING SESSIONS, REACHING 600 PARTICIPANTS EITHER IN-PERSON OR ONLINE. PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL FOCUS AROUND THE 63 ACRES OF CONSERVATION LAND THAT PAPAHANA KUAOLA STEWARDS AND THE IDENTIFIED NATIVE PLANTS THAT FLOURISH ON THE PROPERTY. WITH THE GUIDANCE OF CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS AND NATIVE PLANT SPECIALISTS, STAFF WILL GENERATE ON-LINE CURRICULUM AND HANDS-ON WORKSHOPS TO BRING THESE PERSPECTIVES TO THE COMMUNITY. PARTICIPANTS WILL LEARN SKILLS THAT CAN BE UTILIZED IN EVERYDAY LIFE WHILE DEEPENING THEIR UNDERSTANDING AND APPRECIATION OF HAWAIIAN CULTURE.

THE MELE: SONIC KNOWLEDGE PROJECT WILL DOCUMENT THE UNIQUE PRACTICES OF THE HAKU MELE-THE HAWAIIAN CULTURAL PRACTICE OF KNOWLEDGE PROLIFERATION THROUGH SONG. BY ENGAGING A COHORT OF MASTER HAKU MELE AND CULTURAL EXPERTS, THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE NEW COMPOSITIONS OF MELE TO BE CAPTURED IN EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES IN THE FORM OF AUDIO RECORDINGS, VIDEO INTERVIEWS OF COMPOSERS, AND WRITTEN CURRICULUM ON EACH COMPOSITION TO FULLY EXPLAIN THIS TRADITIONAL PRACTICE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ENGAGE THE SUPPORT OF AN AUDIO ENGINEER AND VIDEOGRAPHER TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE PROJECT RESOURCES, WHICH WILL BE MADE FREELY AVAILABLE ONLINE.

PAPAKU NO KAMEHA'IKANA WILL DOCUMENT THE HISTORY AND LINEAGE OF HULA'THE TRADITIONAL DANCE OF NATIVE HAWAIIAN PEOPLE. ORIGINALLY INTENDED TO BE PASSED FROM MASTER TEACHER TO STUDENT, HULA HAS BEEN POPULARIZED AROUND THE WORLD, RESULTING IN FORMS THAT NO LONGER RESEMBLE THE TRADITIONS HANDED DOWN FROM GENERATION TO GENERATION. THE PROJECT WILL PRODUCE 24 WEBINARS POSTED ONLINE AND 12 WORKSHOPS TARGETING 200 PERSONS. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PRODUCE A BOOK ON HULA LEGACY AND WILL CONDUCT INTERVIEWS WITH DESCENDANTS OF MASTER TEACHERS. EIGHT STUDENTS WILL PARTICIPATE IN COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT, CATALOGING AND APPLICATION DESIGN AS THEY ASSIST WITH THE INTERVIEWS AND THEIR TRANSCRIPTION. THE LONG-TERM GOAL OF THE PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE TRANSMISSION OF THE LEGACY OF HULA, WHICH IS NOT ONLY THE TRADITIONAL HAWAIIAN DANCE BUT ALSO THE FOUNDATION OF ORAL HISTORY, CEREMONY, SPIRITUALITY, HEALING, AND WELLNESS.

KAWAIAHA'O CHURCH HISTORICAL SITE AND ARCHIVES LIBRARY (KHSA), HOUSED IN THE FIRST CHRISTIAN CHURCH BUILT ON OAHU, WILL IMPROVE THE PRESERVATION AND MANAGEMENT OF ITS COLLECTIONS THROUGH A DIGITIZATION PROJECT THAT WILL ALSO PROVIDE PUBLIC ACCESS VIA THE INTERNET AND SOCIAL MEDIA PLATFORMS. COLLECTIONS TO BE DIGITIZED, CATALOGED, AND TRANSCRIBED INCLUDE CHURCH ADMINISTRATION AND SACRAMENTAL RECORDS LAND, BUILDINGS, AND GROUNDS RECORDS AND AUDIO TAPES, MUSIC, AND PHOTOGRAPHS. DOCUMENTS SUCH AS BAPTISM, MARRIAGE, DEATH, AND FUNERAL RECORDS WILL PROVIDE GENEALOGICAL DATA FOR HAWAII RESIDENTS. A PROJECT COORDINATOR AND DIGITAL ARCHIVE SPECIALIST WILL COORDINATE THE PROJECT IN ADDITION TO CREATING A SERIES OF VIDEOS FOR COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO PROVIDE INSTRUCTION ON THE USE OF THE DIGITAL COLLECTIONS TO CONDUCT RESEARCH ON FAMILY HISTORY.

THE SUQUAMISH INDIAN TRIBE WILL UPDATE AN ORAL HISTORY PROJECT CONDUCTED FROM 1981-83 THAT HAS GUIDED THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SUQUAMISH MUSEUM FOR OVER 30 YEARS. THE PROJECT WILL ENGAGE THE 78 SUQUAMISH ELDERS WHO ARE 70 YEARS OF AGE AND OLDER TO DOCUMENT THEIR BIOGRAPHICAL, CULTURAL, AND PERSONAL KNOWLEDGE FOR USE IN MORE CONTEMPORARY PROGRAMMING AND MUSEUM EXHIBITS. ALTHOUGH THE TRIBE RECOGNIZED THE NEED TO GATHER ORAL HISTORIES DURING A RETREAT IN 2018, THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC NOT ONLY INCREASED THE SENSE OF URGENCY BUT PROVIDED TIME TO CONSIDER A PLAN FOR THE PROJECT. COLLECTING ORAL HISTORIES OF EXPERIENCES IN THE MORE RECENT PAST WILL GUIDE LONG RANGE PLANNING AND HELP THE MUSEUM FOCUS ITS COLLECTIONS ACQUISITIONS FOR THE NEXT FORESEEABLE DECADES.

THE SKOKOMISH TRIBE WILL DOCUMENT AND PRESERVE THEIR NATIVE LANGUAGE, TUWADUQ, BEFORE IT BECOMES EXTINCT. THE SKOKOMISH LANGUAGE PROGRAM WILL WORK WITH CONSULTANTS TO SCAN AND DIGITIZE PAPER DOCUMENTS AND COMPILE WORDS AND PHRASES INTO AN ACCESSIBLE DIGITAL DATABASE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL THEN CREATE LANGUAGE BOOKS TO LEARN THE FOUNDATION OF THE TUWADUQ LANGUAGE WITH WORD LISTS, PICTURES, PHRASES OR STORIES THAT HAVE HISTORICALLY DOCUMENTED AUDIO, WHICH WILL ALL BE AVAILABLE FREE TO ALL TRIBAL MEMBERS. THE TRIBE WILL DISTRIBUTE THE BOOKS IN A VARIETY OF WAYS TO BENEFIT BOTH LOCAL MEMBERS AND RESIDENTS AS WELL AS TRIBAL MEMBERS WHO LIVE OFF THE RESERVATION. THE TRIBE WILL MEASURE PROJECT SUCCESS THROUGH FEEDBACK FROM PRINTED AND ONLINE SURVEYS AS WELL AS TRACKING THE NUMBERS OF MATERIAL DOWNLOADS AND VISITORS ACCESSING THE DIGITAL MATERIALS.

THE INSTITUTE FOR NATIVE PACIFIC EDUCATION AND CULTURE WILL ADDRESS LOW SCIENCE AND MATH PROFICIENCY ACHIEVEMENT RATES FOR NATIVE HAWAIIAN STUDENTS BY DESIGNING MORE RELEVANT STEM LEARNING ACTIVITIES. THE INPEACE INDIGENOUS SCIENCE CENTER'S MAHINA EXHIBIT PROJECT WILL CREATE THREE EXHIBIT DESIGNS WITH LEARNING OBJECTIVES TARGETED FOR STUDENTS AGES 4-14. FOCUSED ON THE MAHINA (MOON), THE EXHIBITS AND RELATED ACTIVITIES WILL BE DESIGNED TO BE ENJOYABLE AND THOUGHT-PROVOKING FOR NATIVE HAWAIIAN COMMUNITIES TO ENGAGE IN STEM LEARNING THROUGH A FRAMEWORK THAT IS FAMILIAR. THROUGH CONSULTATION WITH EXPERIENCED EXHIBIT DESIGNERS, THE SCIENCE CENTER'S STAFF WILL GAIN A STRONGER UNDERSTANDING OF BEST PRACTICES IN EXHIBIT DESIGN, AND INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES WILL BENEFIT FROM APPROACHES THAT TRANSLATE THEIR OWN HISTORIES INTO RELEVANT AND FUN STEM LEARNING EXPERIENCES.

IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE KANSAS CITY, KANSAS PUBLIC LIBRARY, THE WYANDOTTE NATION WILL IMPLEMENT THE WYANDOT HERITAGE DIGITAL ARCHIVE: THE WILLIAM E. CONNELLEY COLLECTION PROJECT. THE LIBRARY'S WILLIAM E. CONNELLY COLLECTION INCLUDES THOUSANDS OF DOCUMENTS ABOUT THE HISTORY OF NEGOTIATIONS WITH THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT, THE TRIBE'S REMOVAL FROM OHIO TO KANSAS, AND THE TREATY SIGNED TO PURCHASE LAND IN INDIAN TERRITORY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CATALOG, SCAN, DIGITIZE, AND UPLOAD 8-10,000 DOCUMENTS OF WYANDOT MATERIALS TO A DIGITAL DATABASE CREATED AND UTILIZED BY TRIBAL CITIZENS AND ACCESSIBLE TO RESEARCHERS ACROSS THE NATION. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF TRAINING VIDEOS ON METADATA AND DOCUMENT TRANSCRIPTIONS AS WELL AS A COMMUNITY WORKSHOP ON THE USE OF DIGITAL DATABASES. PROJECT MEMBERS WILL PROMOTE ACTIVITIES AND DISCOVERIES THROUGH VARIOUS FORMS OF SOCIAL MEDIA TO REACH A VARIETY OF AUDIENCES.

THE PONCA TRIBE OF OKLAHOMA WILL ENHANCE LEARNING OF THE PONCA LANGUAGE AND CULTURE BY DEVELOPING AN APP TO CAPTURE RECORDINGS FROM THE FEW REMAINING ELDERS WHO SPEAK ITS ENDANGERED LANGUAGE. THE TRIBE WILL HIRE A CONTRACTOR TO RECORD PONCA SPEAKERS SAYING A TOTAL OF 500 WORDS OR PHRASES ALONG WITH 10 SONGS. THE APP WILL INCLUDE HISTORICAL AND CURRENT PHOTOGRAPHS OF PONCA PEOPLE AS WELL AS A VIDEO, GAMES, AND QUIZZES TO APPEAL TO BOTH CHILDREN AND ADULTS. THE APP WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR FREE DOWNLOAD ON MULTIPLE PLATFORMS FOR ALL 3,925 TRIBAL MEMBERS NO MATTER WHERE THEY LIVE, AND AT A LOW COST FOR THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THE TRIBE WILL RECORD AS MANY OF THE ELDERS AS POSSIBLE, AND THE RECORDINGS WILL ALSO BE EASILY ACCESSIBLE FOR LISTENING IN THE TRIBAL LIBRARY.

THE SEMINOLE TRIBE OF FLORIDA AND THE AH-TAH-THI-KI MUSEUM WILL COMPLETE A CATALOGING AND RESEARCH PROJECT THAT WILL BOTH DECOLONIZE HISTORIC NARRATIVES AND MAKE A HISTORIC NEWSPAPER COLLECTION MORE ACCESSIBLE TO THE MUSEUM’S COMMUNITY. THE TRIBE WILL ENHANCE THE EXISTING CATALOG DESCRIPTIONS OF A COLLECTION OF 18TH AND 19TH CENTURY NEWSPAPERS PUBLISHED BETWEEN 1768 AND 1888 AND MAKE THEM ACCESSIBLE ONLINE. THE NEWSPAPERS SERVE AS A RECORD OF A PERIOD THAT INCLUDED COLONIZATION, WAR, AND GENOCIDE PERPETRATED AGAINST NATIVE POPULATIONS OF THE SOUTHEASTERN U.S. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE THE CREATION OF A FINDING AID AS WELL AS NEWSPAPER AND MAGAZINE ARTICLES THAT WILL ILLUMINATE HOW THE NEWSPAPERS SHAPED THE TELLING OF SEMINOLE HISTORY.

THE EASTERN BAND OF CHEROKEE INDIANS WILL PRODUCE THE EXHIBITION, 'BEHIND THE MASK: CHEROKEE MASK MAKERS AND THEIR LEGACY,' TO REINFORCE THE SIGNIFICANCE OF CHEROKEE MASKS, THEIR HISTORY AND USE, AS WELL AS THEIR MEANING AND SIGNIFICANCE. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON 20TH CENTURY MASK MAKERS, WITH PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON WILL WEST LONG, HIS SON ALLEN LONG, AND THE BIG COVE DANCERS WHO WORE THEIR MASKS. THE EXHIBITION WILL INCLUDE AN INTERPRETIVE CATALOG, A SCHOOL-BASED LEARNING ACTIVITY, AND A PARTICIPATORY EVENT. ALL PROJECT ACTIVITIES WILL TAKE PLACE AT THE CHIEF JOYCE DUGAN CULTURAL ARTS CENTER (CAC) LOCATED ON THE CAMPUS OF THE CHEROKEE CENTRAL SCHOOLS IN THE HEART OF THE QUALLA BOUNDARY--LAND THAT BELONGS TO THE EASTERN BAND OF CHEROKEE INDIANS. THE TRIBE SELECTED CAC AS THE SITE DUE TO ITS DUAL ROLE AS A COMMUNITY CENTER AND SCHOOL RESOURCE.

THE PYRAMID LAKE PAIUTE TRIBE WILL IMPROVE THE CARE AND MANAGEMENT OF THE COLLECTIONS HOUSED AT ITS MUSEUM AND VISITORS' CENTER BY INCREASING STAFF CAPACITY, PROVIDING ACCESS TO NECESSARY TECHNOLOGICAL RESOURCES, AND INSTALLING NEW STORAGE AND DISPLAY EQUIPMENT. THE TRIBE WILL IMPROVE PRESERVATION AND ACCESS FOR THE COLLECTIONS BY IMPLEMENTING AN INVENTORY CONTROL PROCESS; PURCHASING COLLECTIONS MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE, A SCANNER, AND HIGH-DENSITY MOBILE STORAGE CABINETS; AND MODERNIZING EXISTING DISPLAY CASES. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A COLLECTIONS MANAGER WHO WILL PARTICIPATE IN TRAINING TO SUPPORT THE WORK OF INVENTORYING, CATALOGING, AND SCANNING THE COLLECTION MATERIALS.

THE CROW TRIBE WILL LAUNCH A STRATEGIC PLANNING INITIATIVE TO GUIDE THE DEVELOPMENT OF A CULTURAL CENTER ON THE CAMPUS OF LITTLE BIG HORN COLLEGE. A MASTER PLANNER AND AN ARCHITECT WILL LEAD THE PROCESS, AND EACH STAGE WILL INVOLVE STUDENTS, FACULTY AND STAFF, CROW COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND OTHER INTERESTED PARTIES THROUGH SURVEYS AND COMMUNITY MEETINGS. BEYOND STAKEHOLDERS' INPUT, ROTATING MEMBERS OF THE PLANNING COMMITTEE WILL VISIT FOUR CULTURAL CENTERS TO SEE FIRST-HAND HOW OTHER INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES HAVE DEVELOPED THEIR CULTURAL CENTERS. THE WORK TEAM WILL USE THE ACCUMULATED DATA TO GUIDE THE PRODUCTION OF A STRATEGIC PLAN AND THE FINAL CONCEPT PLAN. THE CULTURAL CENTER WILL SERVE AS AN ACCESS POINT ALONG WITH THE TRIBAL LIBRARY AND ARCHIVES TO PERPETUATE CROW CULTURE AND HISTORY THROUGH ROTATING DISPLAYS AND CULTURAL ACTIVITIES ON A REGULAR BASIS.

THE DRY CREEK RANCHERIA BAND OF POMO INDIANS WILL DESIGN AND INSTALL AN EXHIBITION TO REBUILD KNOWLEDGE OF ITS HISTORY AND CULTURE AMONG TRIBAL FAMILIES AND YOUTH AS WELL AS BUILDING GREATER UNDERSTANDING AMONG LOCAL NON-NATIVE AUDIENCES. THE MAJORITY OF TRIBAL MEMBERS LIVE IN SURROUNDING SUBURBS AND CITIES WITH MORE THAN HALF OF ITS POPULATION UNDER THE AGE OF 25. THE EXHIBITION WILL FEATURE HISTORICAL PHOTOGRAPHS, AUDIO FILES OF SOUTHERN POMO LANGUAGE TERMS, ORAL HISTORIES, WORKS OF CELEBRATED BASKET WEAVERS, REPRODUCTIONS OF LOCAL NEWSPAPER ARTICLES, AND FILM FOOTAGE OF MORE CONTEMPORARY AND CONTROVERSIAL EVENTS. AN ACCOMPANYING CATALOG AND PROGRAMMING WILL SUPPORT THE EDUCATIONAL GOALS OF THE PROJECT. THE EXHIBITION WILL TARGET THE GENERAL PUBLIC BY OPENING FOR SIX MONTHS AT THE NEARBY HEALDSBURG MUSEUM. IT WILL THEN BE REFORMATTED FOR INSTALLATION IN THE NEWLY BUILT TRIBAL COMMUNITY SERVICES AND CULTURAL CENTER.

PAPAHANA KUAOLA WILL LAUNCH THE E KANI HOU (TO RESONATE ONCE AGAIN) PROJECT TO INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND UNDERSTANDING OF HAWAIIAN TRADITIONS AND PRACTICES RELATED TO THE UKEKE. THE UKEKE, THE HAWAIIAN MUSICAL BOW, IS THE ONLY INDIGENOUS HAWAIIAN STRINGED INSTRUMENT, AND ONLY A SMALL NUMBER OF CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS ARE FAMILIAR WITH ITS USE AND HISTORY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ORGANIZE CLASSROOM PRESENTATIONS, HANDS-ON ACTIVITIES, AND COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS WITH CULTURAL PRACTITIONERS FOR 300 STUDENTS AND 200 COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN LOW INCOME AND UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. A GUIDE TO SUPPORT EDUCATORS IN TEACHING THE ART OF UKEKE WILL INCLUDE UNITS ON UKEKE HISTORY AND USE BY THE COMMUNITY?S ANCESTORS; WOODS AND OTHER NATURAL RESOURCES AND WHERE THEY CAN BE FOUND; AND DESIGNS AND INSTRUCTIONS FOR MAKING AND STRINGING, STRUMMING, AND COMPOSITIONS.

THE SAN CARLOS APACHE CLANSHIP AND TRADITIONAL APACHE FOOD PROJECT WILL TEACH AND STRENGTHEN THE KNOWLEDGE OF APACHE CLAN SYSTEMS, WHICH PLAY A VITAL ROLE IN THE IDENTITY OF THE APACHE PERSON. THE DIRECTOR OF THE SAN CARLOS APACHE CULTURE CENTER MUSEUM WILL HIRE A PROJECT COORDINATOR TO ORGANIZE PILGRIMAGES TO THE APACHE CLAN HOMELANDS TO LOCATE AND IDENTIFY TRADITIONAL FOODS AND PLANTS, WHICH WILL THEN BE HARVESTED, PROCESSED, AND PREPARED FOR PARTICIPANTS TO CONSUME. THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE WORKSHOPS, A CONFERENCE, AND THE PRODUCTION OF RELATED VIDEOS AND OTHER MATERIALS. PRE- AND POST-PARTICIPATION SURVEYS WILL HELP TO MEASURE THE PROJECT?S SUCCESS AT INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF THE MUSEUM STAFF AND TRIBAL MEMBERS OF ALL AGES TO BETTER UNDERSTAND THEMSELVES CULTURALLY AND TO REDISCOVER HEALTHY, NATURAL, TRADITIONAL FOODS THAT ARE AVAILABLE AT THEIR TRADITIONAL CLAN HOMELANDS.

THE BISHOP MUSEUM WILL INCREASE PUBLIC KNOWLEDGE OF HAWAIIAN CULTURE BY IMPROVING AND STRENGTHENING ITS VOLUNTEER DOCENT PROGRAM. THE MUSEUM WILL ESTABLISH THE POSITION OF DOCENT PROGRAM COORDINATOR TO GUIDE ITS EFFORTS TO RECRUIT AND DIVERSIFY A NEW CORPS OF DOCENTS, ENHANCE VISITOR ENGAGEMENT, AND PROVIDE CULTURAL COMPETENCY TRAINING FOR ITS CURRENT AND FUTURE VOLUNTEERS. THE MUSEUM WILL ALSO PROVIDE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE NEW DOCENT COORDINATOR WHILE EVALUATING THE CURRENT PROGRAMMING, WORKING WITH A CONSULTANT TO DEVELOP NEW TOUR CONTENT AND PRESENTATION TECHNIQUES AND BUILDING A STRONG COMMUNICATION AND SUSTAINABILITY PLAN FOR THE PROGRAM.

THE NATIVE VILLAGE OF EYAK'S ILANKA CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM WILL PURCHASE A HANDHELD 3D DIGITAL SCANNER TO CREATE A VIRTUAL REALITY STORY FOR MUSEUM VISITORS TO LEARN ABOUT AND USE TRIBAL ARTIFACTS IN THEIR TRADITIONAL MANNER. MANY OF THE TRIBE?S ARTIFACTS HAVE BEEN WIDELY DISPERSED, MAKING IT DIFFICULT FOR MEMBERS TO SEE AND INTERACT WITH THEM. A COMPANY EXPERIENCED IN 3D SCANNING AND IMMERSIVE VIRTUAL REALITY SIMULATIONS WILL PROVIDE THE TRAINING, WHICH WILL BE OPEN TO ALL TRIBAL MEMBERS. THE MUSEUM WILL PRODUCE SCANS OF SELECTED OBJECTS COLLECTED OVER THE PAST 15 YEARS. THE NEW EXHIBITION WILL FEATURE THE WORDS AND VOICES OF TRIBAL MEMBERS, PARTICULARLY ELDERS WHO CAN SHARE THEIR STORIES AND HISTORICAL KNOWLEDGE. THE MOBILE SCANNER WILL OFFER MULTIPLE OTHER BENEFITS FOR THE MUSEUM TO CREATE 3D PRINTED COPIES OF RARE ITEMS FOR USE IN CULTURAL PERFORMANCES.

THE SHARING HISTORY PROJECT WILL TRANSFORM THE LARGEST COMPILATION OF SHAWNEE HISTORY INTO A DOCUMENTED, ARCHIVALLY STORED, AND PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE ARCHIVE. FOUR STAFF MEMBERS WILL ENHANCE THEIR SKILLS BY PARTICIPATING IN A SERIES OF ONLINE TRAINING COURSES IN COLLECTIONS CARE, MANAGEMENT, AND RELATED TOPICS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON THE COLLECTIONS ASSEMBLED BY HISTORIAN AND SHAWNEE DESCENDANT RANDOLPH NOE, WHO SPENT DECADES COMPILING MORE THAN 4,000 RECORDS DOCUMENTING THE SHAWNEE PEOPLE FROM PRE-CONTACT THROUGH THE 20TH CENTURY. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL CREATE AN INVENTORY, RE-HOUSE ITEMS IN ARCHIVAL MATERIALS, TRANSFER APPROXIMATELY TWO DOZEN MICROFILM ROLLS AND VARIOUS DISCS TO CURRENT MEDIA, DIGITIZE 750 ITEMS, AND ADD 550 ITEMS TO THE TRIBE?S ONLINE CONTENT MANAGEMENT SYSTEM. THE PROJECT WILL ALSO INCLUDE THE CREATION OF A COLLECTIONS ACQUISITION PLAN TO GUIDE FUTURE COLLECTING FOR THE SHAWNEE TRIBE CULTURAL CENTER.

THE CATAWBA INDIAN NATION WILL CREATE A COMMUNITY RESOURCE CENTER TO CONSOLIDATE ITS LIBRARY COLLECTIONS, ARCHIVES, AND RELATED MATERIALS THAT ARE CURRENTLY DISPERSED IN DIFFERENT LOCATIONS. THE NEW SPACE WILL SUPPORT EXPANDED OPERATIONAL HOURS AND IMPROVED HANDICAP ACCESS. THE TRIBE WILL HIRE A LIBRARY COORDINATOR, PURCHASE SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT THE NEW CENTER, AND PLAN AND IMPLEMENT ACTIVITIES FOR YOUTH AND ADULTS IN THE CATAWBA COMMUNITY. ACTIVITIES MAY INCLUDE BOOK CLUBS, LIBRARY VISITS, CULTURAL STUDIES, GENEALOGY CLUBS, AND GED PROGRAMMING AND TUTORING. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO LEARNING RESOURCES IN A SINGLE SAFE LOCATION TO HELP SHARE THE HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE CATAWBA NATION TO YOUNG PEOPLE AND OTHER PATRONS.

WYANDOTTE NATION WILL CREATE A NEW WEBSITE AND DIGITAL DATABASE OF PRIMARY HISTORICAL SOURCES ASSOCIATED WITH THE 17TH TO 20TH CENTURY HURON/WYANDOT EXPERIENCE IN WISCONSIN, MICHIGAN, OHIO, KANSAS, AND OKLAHOMA. THE NATION?S CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM WILL HOST THE WYANDOTTE HERITAGE DIGITAL ARCHIVE UNDER THE AUSPICES OF THE TRIBAL HERITAGE DEPARTMENT. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ASSEMBLE DIGITAL VERSIONS OF PRIMARY HISTORICAL RESOURCES COLLECTED FROM PUBLIC AND PRIVATE ARCHIVES, LIBRARIES, MUSEUMS, HISTORICAL SOCIETIES, AND COLLECTIONS. THE PROJECT STAFF WILL WORK WITH A STUDENT INTERN TO PERFORM BIBLIOGRAPHIC REFERENCING, CATALOGING, AND SCANNING, PRIOR TO UPLOADING THE DIGITIZED FILES. THE PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE PRESERVATION AND ACCESSIBILITY OF DISPERSED CULTURAL COLLECTIONS, FOSTER GREATER UNDERSTANDING OF TRIBAL VALUES AND TRADITIONS, AND PROMOTE CROSS-CULTURAL EDUCATION, WHILE PROVIDING ACCESS TO ALL TRIBAL MEMBERS AND OTHERS NATIONWIDE.

THE HULA PRESERVATION SOCIETY WILL PROVIDE ACCESS TO A COLLECTION OF PRIMARY SOURCE DIGITAL LEARNING RESOURCES IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE UNIVERSITY OF HAWAII SYSTEM AND THE HAWAI?I STATE PUBLIC LIBRARY. THE SOCIETY WILL COMPLETE FULL TRANSCRIPTS OF ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS WITH 25 INDIVIDUAL NATIVE ELDERS AND FIVE ELDER-BASED PUBLIC PANEL DISCUSSIONS, TOTALING 150 HOURS OF PRIMARY SOURCE MATERIALS AND 7,000 PAGES OF WORD-FOR-WORD DIALOG. THE PROJECT WILL PROVIDE ACCESS FOR THE FIRST TIME TO ORAL HISTORY RESOURCES THAT EXIST NOWHERE ELSE, CREATED OVER THE LAST 20 YEARS WITH THE GOAL OF SHARING THE MEMORIES, SONGS, AND DANCES OF KUMU HULA AND NATIVE ELDERS WITH FUTURE GENERATIONS. THE SOCIETY WILL MAKE THESE NEW DIGITAL LEARNING RESOURCES WIDELY AND FREELY AVAILABLE ONLINE THROUGH ITS WEBSITE AND ITS PARTNER NETWORKS.

THE CHICKALOON NATIVE VILLAGE WILL IMPLEMENT THE NAY?DINI?AA NA? KAYAX NAHWGHOLNICDE PROJECT TO CREATE A RECORD OF INDIGENOUS PEOPLES? MILITARY CONTRIBUTIONS AND THE EFFECTS OF WAR SERVICE ON THEIR LIVES. A MUSEUM SPECIALIST WILL COORDINATE ACTIVITIES INVOLVING RE-HOUSING AND DIGITIZING A COLLECTION OF MATERIALS THAT DOCUMENTS THE WORLD WAR II MILITARY EXPERIENCE THROUGH THE EYES OF A CHICKALOON NATIVE VILLAGE TRIBAL CITIZEN. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL ALSO RECORD ORAL HISTORY INTERVIEWS WITH UP TO 14 TRIBAL CITIZENS WHO ARE VETERANS OF MILITARY SERVICE, MANY OF WHOM ARE ELDERS. THE ORAL HISTORIES WILL BE ENHANCED WITH PHOTOGRAPHS, DOCUMENTS, OR OTHER MATERIALS FROM EACH INTERVIEWEE. THE RESULTING PRODUCTS WILL BE ACCESSIBLE ON THE TRIBE?S DIGITAL ARCHIVAL PLATFORM, AND THE RECORDINGS WILL BE INCLUDED IN THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS' VETERANS HISTORY PROJECT, EXPANDING THE PUBLIC?S ABILITY TO ENGAGE WITH AND LEARN FROM THEM.

KAW NATION WILL PLAN AND IMPLEMENT DIGITIZATION ACTIVITIES TO PROVIDE FOR THE PRESERVATION OF TRIBAL ARTIFACTS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND OTHER ITEMS OF HISTORICAL SIGNIFICANCE. THE PROJECT TEAM WILL PURCHASE SUPPLIES AND EQUIPMENT TO SUPPORT THE WORK, INCLUDING SCANNERS, A PRINTER, AND PRESERVATION/STORAGE MATERIALS.
