IN A TIME OF UNCERTAINTY, THE NAVAJO NATION MUSEUM WILL CREATE PROGRAMMING THAT SAFELY BRINGS FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES TOGETHER THROUGH AN ANIMATED NAVAJO COYOTE STORIES SERIES?CLASSIC TRADITIONAL TEACHINGS THAT ARE USUALLY TOLD DURING THE WINTER MONTHS. THE MUSEUM WILL CREATE THIS SERIES IN THE NAVAJO LANGUAGE WITH AN OPTION FOR ENGLISH SUBTITLES AND ORGANIZE THE SCREENS USING A DRIVE-IN THEATER FORMAT. THEY WILL HOLD THESE SHOWINGS ACROSS THE NAVAJO NATION AT CHAPTER HOUSES AND COMMUNITY CENTERS SO THAT FAMILIES CAN ENJOY AND LEARN THE NAVAJO COYOTE STORIES FROM THE SAFETY OF THEIR VEHICLES.

THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF GRAND RONDE WILL SERVE AT-RISK TRIBAL ELDERS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO WERE IMPACTED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY HIRING A PART-TIME LIBRARY AIDE WHO WILL STAFF A MOBILE LIBRARY FOR ELDERS AND OTHERS. THE TRIBE ALSO WILL PURCHASE TWO LAPTOPS TO CREATE VIDEO STORIES, AS WELL AS EIGHT IPADS FOR A LOAN PROGRAM, SO MORE COMMUNITY MEMBERS CAN ACCESS DIGITAL RESOURCES. FINALLY, THEY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO IMPROVING LIBRARY SAFETY BY PURCHASING PLEXIGLASS COUNTER SHIELDS FOR THE LIBRARY, AS WELL AS A NO-CONTACT BOOK RETURN BIN.

TAMASTSLIKT CULTURAL INSTITUTE WILL ENHANCE ITS DIGITAL CONTENT AND REMOTE WORK CAPABILITIES, PROVIDE SALARY SUPPORT FOR PROJECT-RELATED STAFF AND TASKS, AND INCREASE SAFEGUARDS SPECIFIC TO COVID-19 WITHIN THE FACILITY. THROUGH WWW.TAMASTSLIKT.ORG, THEY WILL INCREASE OFFERINGS TO THE PUBLIC SO THAT THEY CAN BENEFIT FROM THE COLLECTIONS, EXHIBITS, AND PROGRAMS FROM THE SAFETY OF THEIR HOME OR OFFICE. VIRTUAL TOURS, ACCESS TO COLLECTIONS, AND LIVE STREAMING WILL MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE HISTORY AND CULTURES OF THE PEOPLES NOW KNOWN AS THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF UMATILLA?THE CAYUSE, UMATILLA, AND WALLA WALLA?WHILE SOCIAL DISTANCING.

HI?IPAKA, LLC WILL PRESERVE JOBS BY TRAINING STAFF AND DEVELOPING CONTENT TO ADDRESS THE DIGITAL DIVIDE, PROVIDE TECHNICAL SUPPORT, AND BUILD CAPACITY FOR DIGITAL INCLUSION OF AND ENGAGEMENT WITH THE BOTANICAL GARDEN AND LIBRARY AUDIENCE AT WAIMEA VALLEY, OAHU. IN THIS WAY, THE STAFF WILL BE BETTER ABLE TO SUSTAIN THE INVALUABLE CULTURAL CONNECTIONS, ECONOMIC RESOURCES, AND VITAL INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE COLLECTION. HI?IPAKA?S GOAL IS TO PRESERVE AND PERPETUATE THE HUMAN, CULTURAL, AND NATURAL RESOURCES OF WAIMEA VALLEY FOR GENERATIONS THROUGH EDUCATION AND STEWARDSHIP. THE PROJECT WILL CREATE THE FULL RANGE OF DIGITAL CONTENT, INCLUDING ONLINE VIDEOS, DIGITAL CURRICULUM LESSON PLANS, INTERACTIVE VIRTUAL MAPS, INFORMATIONAL WEBSITE POSTS, INTERACTIVE ONLINE SEMINARS (WEBINARS), AN INTEGRATED DIGITAL LIBRARY CATALOG SYSTEM AND MAPPED DATABASE,  AS WELL AS OFFER TRAINED STAFF TO SUPPORT THE USE AND SUSTAINABILITY OF THESE PRODUCTS.

THE SEMINOLE AH-TAH-THI-KI MUSEUM?S PROJECT WILL SUPPORT THE FUNDING OF THEIR EXHIBIT DESIGN AND MEDIA SPECIALIST POSITION TO HELP ADDRESS THE CHALLENGES FACED BY THE MUSEUM DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. MORE THAN 80 PERCENT OF THE MUSEUM?S FULL- AND PART-TIME STAFF HAVE BEEN PLACED ON A TEMPORARY FURLOUGH. THE DESIGN AND MEDIA SPECIALIST?RESPONSIBLE FOR MAINTAINING EXHIBITS, DEVELOPING EXHIBIT CONCEPTS AND LAYOUTS, IMPLEMENTING MEDIA AND DIGITAL ASSETS, AND ENSURING ARTISTIC QUALITY?IS CRITICAL TO ENSURING THAT THE TRIBAL COMMUNITY AND PUBLIC STAY ENGAGED DURING AND AFTER THE PANDEMIC. BY SECURING THE POSITION, THEY WILL BE ABLE TO PROPERLY MAINTAIN AND UPDATE THE MUSEUM?S PERMANENT EXHIBITS.

IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THE HAWAIIAN MISSION HOUSES HISTORIC SITE AND ARCHIVES (HMH) WILL CREATE A LIVESTREAM VERSION OF A CULTURAL-BASED HANDS-ON FIELD TRIP THAT TOOK PLACE A FEW YEARS PRIOR TO SERVE THE STUDENTS AND TEACHERS OF HAWAII. IN THE 2017?2018 SCHOOL YEAR, WITH FUNDS FROM A CITY AND COUNTY GRANT-IN-AID, HMH SERVED NEARLY 5,000 STUDENTS, INCLUDING 1,507 TITLE 1 STUDENTS. THE NEXT SCHOOL YEAR, THE FIELD TRIP PROGRAM INCREASED BY 14 PERCENT WITH STUDENTS COMING FROM 102 SCHOOLS, ALL ENGAGING WITH 19TH CENTURY HISTORY THROUGH HANDS-ON, CULTURAL-BASED LEARNING.

MUSCOGEE CREEK NATION WILL REDUCE THE DIGITAL DIVIDE THAT COLLEGE OF THE MUSCOGEE NATION (CMN) STUDENTS ARE FACING WHILE THEY CONTINUE THEIR EDUCATION AT HOME DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE CMN THE OPPORTUNITY TO PURCHASE THE CHAT-A-LIBRARIAN AND LIBGUIDES SOFTWARE, WHICH WILL ALLOW THE LIBRARIAN TO SPEAK WITH STUDENTS VIRTUALLY, PROVIDE STUDENTS WITH RESEARCH INFORMATION, AND CREATE A WAY FOR STUDENTS TO REACH OUT WHEN THEY NEED HELP. IN ADDITION TO THE SOFTWARE, 68 STUDENTS ALSO WILL RECEIVE INTERNET-ENABLED LAPTOP COMPUTERS AND DATA INTERNET CARDS WHILE ATTENDING CLASSES REMOTELY.

THE POEH CULTURAL CENTER WILL CREATE A TRIBAL MUSEUM REOPENING GUIDE, SUPPORTED BY TRAINING RESOURCES THAT ARE AVAILABLE FOR FREE ON THE WEB, TO ORGANIZATIONS THAT ARE FACING CHALLENGES DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THROUGH PLANNED COLLABORATIONS, STAFF WILL COMPILE A RESOURCE BASE THAT INCLUDES CASE STUDIES RELATED TO CHALLENGES AND SOLUTIONS THAT INSTITUTIONS HAVE FACED AS A RESULT OF THE PANDEMIC, TECHNOLOGICAL RESOURCES AND ADVISEMENT IN DEVELOPING MULTIMEDIA CONTENT FOR PUBLIC PROGRAMMING AND ACCESS, AND PUBLIC SAFETY POLICY AND PROCEDURE ADVISEMENT FOR CENTERS AS THEY GRADUALLY REOPEN TO THE PUBLIC.

BLUE LAKE RANCHERIA WILL ADDRESS THE NEED FOR DIGITAL CONNECTIVITY IDENTIFIED BY NUMEROUS REQUESTS FROM SYLVIA DANIELS MEMORIAL LIBRARY PATRONS BY OFFERING EBOOKS, EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES, AND ACCESS TO LIBRARY COLLECTIONS DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THIS PROJECT WILL BENEFIT THE ENTIRE COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING LEARNING, COMMUNICATIONS, AND ACCESS OPPORTUNITIES TO THE 203 RESIDENTS AND MORE THAN 300 EMPLOYEES OF THE RANCHERIA. AFTER THIS PROJECT IS COMPLETE, THE COMMUNITY WILL HAVE ACCESS TO THE DIGITAL CONNECTIVITY THEY NEED FOR IMPORTANT RESOURCES AND INFORMATION DESPITE POWER OUTAGES, QUARANTINE, AND OTHER INCIDENTS THAT MAKE PHYSICAL VISITS IMPOSSIBLE.

ZUNI PUBLIC LIBRARY IN THE PUEBLO OF ZUNI, NEW MEXICO, WILL ADDRESS THE INEQUITIES IN DIGITAL ACCESS THAT HAVE BEEN MADE APPARENT DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC THROUGH THEIR SOLUTIONS FOR THE FUTURE PROJECT. THEY WILL PROVIDE THEIR STUDENT POPULATION WITH AN INCREASED LENDING PROGRAM OF INTERNET-ACCESSIBLE COMPUTERS FOR HOME USE CREATE INCREASED ONLINE LIBRARY PROGRAMMING SO THAT ACTIVITIES INTERRUPTED BY PANDEMIC CLOSURES CAN BE FACILITATED IN STUDENTS? HOMES AND OFFER SERVICES TO STUDENTS WHOSE HOMES ARE NOT SERVED BY ANY INTERNET PROVIDER TO ACT AS AN EDUCATIONAL LIFELINE DURING SCHOOL CLOSURES.

THE MONACAN MUSEUM COVID RESPONSE AND SUSTAINABILITY PROJECT WILL REOPEN THE MUSEUM AND HISTORIC COMPLEX TO VISITORS BASED ON HEALTH AND SAFETY GUIDELINES, PROMOTE MUSEUM COLLECTIONS AND TRIBAL HISTORY DIGITALLY, AND PLAN FOR THE FUTURE GROWTH AND ACCESSIBILITY OF THE MUSEUM AND TRIBE?S HISTORIC AND CULTURAL RESOURCES. THE PROJECT STAFF WILL SUPPORT THESE GOALS BY CREATING AND IMPLEMENTING A HEALTH AND SAFETY PROTOCOL AND CREATING, PRODUCING, AND PUBLISHING DIGITAL CONTENT INCLUDING A VIDEO ON A NEW MUSEUM WEBSITE AND OTHER MEDIA PLATFORMS.

IN RESPONSE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, SUSANVILLE INDIAN RANCHERIA?S EDUCATION PROGRAM WILL SHAPE THEIR TUTORING PROGRAM BY PROVIDING LAPTOPS TO MORE THAN 100 STUDENTS FOR DISTANCE EDUCATION. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL PROVIDE COORDINATION BETWEEN TUTORS, STUDENTS, PARENTS, AND TEACHERS FOR MORE EFFECTIVE STUDENT PARTICIPATION AND ACHIEVEMENT. MANY K?12 STUDENTS LACK DEVICES TO ATTEND SCHOOL ONLINE AND COMPLETE DISTANCE EDUCATION. AN ACHIEVEMENT GAP EXISTS BETWEEN NATIVE STUDENTS AND THEIR PEERS DATA SUGGESTS THAT THE NATIVE STUDENTS IN THEIR PROGRAM FELL EVEN FURTHER BEHIND WHEN THEIR SCHOOLS CLOSED DUE TO COVID-19. BY PROVIDING LAPTOPS FOR THESE STUDENTS AND TRAINING FOR STAFF, STUDENTS, AND PARENTS TO USE PLATFORMS SUCH AS GOOGLE CLASSROOM, MICROSOFT TEAMS, AND ZOOM, THEY WILL CONTINUE TO CLOSE THE ACHIEVEMENT GAP.

ALEUTIAN PRIBILOF ISLANDS ASSOCIATION, INC.?S PROJECT?OPERATION BOOT STRAP?WILL FOCUS ON BUILDING CAPACITY BY PROVIDING TRAINING FOR UNANGAX HERITAGE LIBRARY AND ARCHIVE STAFF IN BASIC, INTERMEDIATE, AND ADVANCED SKILLS NECESSARY TO CREATE AND PUBLISH EDUCATIONAL AND HISTORICAL VIDEOS ON UNANGAX/ALEUT TOPICS. TO KEEP UP WITH THE CHANGING ROLES OF LIBRARIES DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, THEY WANTED TO BUILD THEIR LIBRARY OF EDUCATIONAL AND HISTORICAL VIDEOS THAT DYNAMICALLY PORTRAY UNANGAX CULTURE AND TRADITIONS BY COLLABORATING WITH TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO POSSESS TRADITIONAL KNOWLEDGE. RATHER THAN CONTRACT WITH PRODUCTION VENDORS FOR THE VIDEOS, THEY WILL LEARN HOW TO CREATE THEM ON THEIR OWN.

THE COUSHATTA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA WILL MODIFY OPEN LANDS ADJOINING THE TRIBAL MUSEUM TO CREATE INNOVATIVE OUTDOOR AREAS AND ADAPTATIONS TO EXISTING EXHIBITS TO SAFELY REOPEN THE MUSEUM. THIS PROJECT WILL SAFELY DISINFECT THE MUSEUM INTERIOR AND REDUCE CROWDING INSIDE THE BUILDING BY MODIFYING EXISTING EXHIBITS TO INCLUDE BOTH INDOOR AND OUTDOOR ELEMENTS DEVELOPING OUTDOOR WORK AND DEMONSTRATION AREAS FOR TRIBAL ARTISANS DEVELOPING NEW TRAINING CURRICULUM FOR YOUTH TO SERVE AS MUSEUM GUIDES INSTALLING OUTDOOR HAND-WASHING AND SAFETY STATIONS FOR ARTISANS AND VISITORS AND INSTALLING OUTDOOR VIEWING AND SEATING AREAS FOR FILMS AND OTHER EVENTS. THEY EXPECT THAT PROJECT BENEFITS AND PRODUCTS, INCLUDING REVISED INTERPRETIVE MATERIALS AND INTERACTIVE ACTIVITIES, WILL ENHANCE THE OVERALL VISITOR EXPERIENCE FOR MANY YEARS TO COME.

THE KALISPEL TRIBAL LIBRARY WILL CREATE A SAFE SPACE FOR LIBRARY PATRONS TO MAINTAIN SOCIAL DISTANCING WHILE IN THE LIBRARY, PROVIDE GERM SCREENS AND A BARCODE READER AT THE LIBRARY RESOURCE SPECIALIST?S WORK STATION TO PROTECT BOTH PATRONS AND LIBRARY PERSONNEL, AND LOCATE AN OUTDOOR BOOK RETURN RECEPTACLE FOR CONTACTLESS RETURN OF LIBRARY RESOURCES. NEARLY 500 COMMUNITY MEMBERS WILL BENEFIT FROM THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THIS PROJECT. THEY HOPE TO PROVIDE LIBRARY SERVICES FOR THE KALISPEL TRIBAL COMMUNITY WHILE INSTITUTING ADDITIONAL SAFETY PRECAUTIONS TO LIMIT EXPOSURE AND TRANSMISSION OF COVID-19.

TO SUPPORT NATIVE HAWAIIAN FIRST-TIME FRESHMAN STUDENTS FROM UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, THE HAWAII PACIFIC UNIVERSITY LIBRARIES WILL EXPAND ITS ONLINE COLLECTION AND DELIVER LIBRARY INFORMATION LITERACY PROGRAMS. THE PANDEMIC HAS CREATED A SHIFT TOWARD INCREASED ONLINE LEARNING, WHICH WILL BE SUPPORTED BY EXPANDING THE AVAILABILITY OF EBOOKS, STREAMING VIDEO, AND ONLINE LITERACY WORKSHOPS DESIGNED TO INTRODUCE NEW STUDENTS TO AVAILABLE LIBRARY RESOURCES. THE GOAL IS TO SUPPORT FIRST-YEAR ACADEMIC SUCCESS AND INCREASE THE LIKELIHOOD FOR STUDENTS TO ACHIEVE AN OVERALL GPA OF 2.0.

CATAWBA NATION'S CULTURAL DIVISION HAS PARTNERED WITH THE PRATT INSTITUTE FACULTY AND STAFF, TO DEVELOP A NEW EXHIBITION REGARDING THE PAST AND PRESENT EXPERIENCE OF CATAWBAS WITH EPIDEMIC DISEASES WHILE DEVELOPING NEW POLICIES, PROCEDURES, AS WELL AS A 5-YEAR EXHIBITION PLAN. THE GOAL IS TO CREATE AND UNVEIL A NEW EXHIBITION ABOUT PAST AND CONTEMPORARY CATAWBA EXPERIENCES OF EPIDEMIC/PANDEMIC DISEASE.  IT IS ESSENTIAL FOR THE COMMUNITY TO CONTINUE CREATING AND TELLING STORIES AND THE CATAWBA CULTURAL CENTER IS UNIQUELY POSITIONED TO SUPPORT THAT PROCESS THROUGH THE USE OF ITS STAFF, PARTNERS, AND SPACE. THE EXHIBITION WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE WELL-BEING OF CATAWBAS AND NON-CATAWBAS ALIKE BOTH IN THE FUTURE AND THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF 'SURVIVING PANDEMIC' EXHIBITION.

DUE TO THE INCREASED DEMAND FOR ONLINE ACCESS TO COLLECTION MATERIALS THAT HAS BEEN ACCELERATED BY THE PANDEMIC, THE SQUAXIN ISLAND MUSEUM, LIBRARY AND RESEARCH CENTER WILL DIGITIZE EXISTING MUSEUM MATERIALS INTO EASILY ACCESSIBLE ONLINE CONTENT. THE GOAL WILL BE TO MAKE THESE TEACHINGS AVAILABLE TO THE COMMUNITY, AS WELL AS PROVIDE RESOURCES AND OUTREACH TO EDUCATE A BROADER AUDIENCE IN MAKING USE OF THE MATERIALS. THIS WILL INCLUDE CLASSROOM GATHERINGS, OUTREACH EVENTS, HOME VISITS AND INDIVIDUALLY SCHEDULED TRAININGS.

THE CONFEDERATED TRIBES OF THE COLVILLE INDIAN IN NESPELEM, WASHINGTON, IS PLANNING TO PROVIDE TRUSTED SPACES AND DELIVER PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO FAMILIES, GROUPS, AND INDIVIDUALS OF ALL CULTURAL AND SOCIOECONOMIC BACKGROUNDS. THE COMMUNITY WILL ENGAGE IN DIALOGUE THAT WILL FOSTER RECOVERY AND REBUILDING POST COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THEY WILL REPLACE FLOORING, UPDATE LIGHTING, MAKE WALL REPAIRS, AND WORK WITH RESIDENTS TO CREATE A COMMUNITY-BASED MURAL IN EACH OF THE COLVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARIES LOCATIONS. THE PROJECT ALSO WILL ESTABLISH TECHNOLOGY RESOURCE CENTERS BY PROVIDING UP-TO-DATE COMPUTERS, INTERNET ACCESS, AND MACHINES FOR PRINTING, COPYING, SCANNING, AND FAXING. THIS PROJECT WILL PROVIDE A HOME FOR COMMUNITY EVENTS AND PROGRAMMING THAT WILL ASSIST IN THE MENTAL WELLBEING OF COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

HI-IPAKA, LLC IN HALEIWA, HAWAII, WILL ORGANIZE A SERIES OF CULTURAL COMMUNITY EVENTS FOR DIVERSE AUDIENCES IN THE WAIMEA VALLEY, A CULTURAL PRESERVATION SITE WITH ARCHAEOLOGICAL SITES, BOTANICAL GARDENS, AND NATIVE AND ENDANGERED BIRDS. HI-IPAKA-SPONSORED WALKING TOURS, SCHOOL PROGRAMS, WORKSHOPS, AND HAWAIIAN CULTURAL DEMONSTRATIONS AT THE WAIMEA VALLEY HAVE BEEN CANCELLED SINCE THE ONSET OF THE PANDEMIC. IN 2022, HI-IPAKA WILL DEVELOP AND DELIVER FIVE NEW EVENTS THAT HELP THE COMMUNITY SAFELY GATHER AND RECOVER FROM THE PANDEMIC, FEATURING A HULA EXHIBITION AND LEI-MAKING CONTEST, HAWAIIAN LANGUAGE AND MUSIC, AND AN HEIRLOOM PLANT WORKSHOP. HI-IPAKA WILL PROMOTE THE EVENTS WIDELY TO ENCOURAGE PARTICIPATION BY NATIVE HAWAIIAN RESIDENTS OF OAHU AS WELL AS VISITORS FROM NEIGHBORING ISLANDS AND AROUND THE WORLD.

LANGUAGE LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES SLOWED DURING THE COVID19 PANDEMIC DUE TO THE HEALTH ORDER THAT RESTRICTED INDOOR GATHERINGS, SCHOOL ATTENDANCE AND OTHER GATHERINGS OUTSIDE OF FAMILY PODS FOR OVER A YEAR. TO ASSIST WITH RECOVERY FOR THE MAKAH COMMUNITY, THE MAKAH CULTURAL AND RESEARCH CENTER WILL ENHANCE STEWARDSHIP OF ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS BY DIGITIZING ANALOG TAPES AND CREATING ACCESS TOOLS FOR COLLECTIONS. INCREASED STAFF SKILLS WILL BE DEMONSTRATED BY PROFICIENT USE OF THE EUDICO LINGUISTIC ANNOTATOR (ELAN) OPEN SOURCE SOFTWARE. AN INCREASE IN MAKAH LANGUAGE SPEAKERS WILL BE DEMONSTRATED BY AN UPSURGE IN TRIBAL MEMBERS SPEAKING THE MAKAH LANGUAGE ON A DAILY BASIS.

THE COUSHATTA TRIBE OF LOUISIANA WILL CREATE AN INDOOR-OUTDOOR EXHIBIT BASED ON THE KOASATI CONCEPT OF IHOOCHASTONTIHCHOTOK (BRINGING (SOMETHING) FROM THE PAST INTO THE FUTURE). IT WILL INCLUDE A SERIES OF IMMERSIVE, INTERCONNECTED, MUSEUM WALKING AND DRIVING EXHIBITS THAT SHOW VISITORS HOW THE LONG-AGO TIME (IHOOCHAKITTAP) AND PRESENT TIME ARE CONNECTED THROUGH DAILY HABITS, VALUES, AND SHARED ACTIVITIES. BOTH ONLINE AND IN-PERSON OPTIONS FOR PARTICIPATION WILL BE AVAILABLE. ON-SITE, THEY WILL REPLACE HIGH-TOUCH IMBEDDED DIGITAL DISPLAY SURFACES WITH IPADS THAT CAN BE SWAPPED OUT AND CLEANED SEVERAL TIMES A DAY TO RESPOND TO PANDEMIC-RELATED ISSUES. THEY ALSO PLAN TO EXPAND OUTDOOR WORK AND DEMONSTRATION AREAS FOR TRIBAL ARTISANS AND OUTDOOR INTERACTIVE AND EXPERIENTIAL EXHIBIT AREAS. THESE NEW EXHIBITS RESPOND TO THE NEED TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITY CONNECTIONS AND HEALING THROUGH EXHIBITIONS, PROGRAMS AND EVENTS THAT HIGHLIGHT THEIR CULTURAL RESILIENCY FOLLOWING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC.

THE OJIBWE LEARNING CENTER AND LIBRARY (OLCL) IN MICHIGAN WILL BUILD A DIGITAL PRESENCE TO ALLOW MEMBERS OF THE SAULT STE. MARIE TRIBE OF CHIPPEWA INDIANS AND THEIR NEIGHBORS TO ACCESS ITS COLLECTIONS OF ARTIFACTS, VIDEOS, PHOTOGRAPHS, AND DOCUMENTS, IN ADDITION TO ORIGINAL CONTENT FROM THE LANGUAGE AND CULTURE DEPARTMENT. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, COMMUNITY MEMBERS WERE UNABLE TO VISIT THE FACILITY AND ENGAGE IN ITS CULTURAL PROGRAMMING, EXACERBATING CONDITIONS ENDANGERING CULTURAL CONTINUITY. THROUGH DEDICATED AND CREATIVE MEASURES, STAFF PROVIDED LIMITED LANGUAGE AND CULTURAL PROGRAMMING THROUGH LANGUAGE LESSONS, STORYTELLING, AND TEACHINGS. TO MEET THIS NEED TODAY AND SUSTAIN COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT THROUGH DIFFICULT TIMES, OLCL MUST BUILD ITS CAPABILITIES TO CREATE A DIGITAL ARCHIVE THAT PROVIDES ACCESS TO ALL COMMUNITY MEMBERS. ONCE THIS IS COMPLETED, OLCL WILL BE ABLE TO MEET THE TECHNOLOGICAL CHALLENGES OF ITS PROGRAMMING THROUGH ITS SERVICE AREA AND BEYOND.

THE TOLOWA DEE-NI NATION IN SMITH RIVER, CALIFORNIA, WILL EXPAND LIBRARY SERVICES IN THE COMMUNITY THROUGH THE PURCHASE OF AN OUTREACH VEHICLE. THE NATION WILL USE THIS INVESTMENT TO DEVELOP A MOBILE RESOURCE LIBRARY THAT WILL PROVIDE ACCESS FOR THOSE WHO ARE UNABLE OR UNWILLING TO COME TO THE LIBRARY'S MAIN BUILDING. PATRONS WILL BE ABLE TO CHECK OUT BOOKS AND WILL HAVE ACCESS TO EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS AND FAMILY SUPPORT RESOURCES. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL OPERATE A DIGITAL RECORDING PRODUCTION STUDIO TO PRODUCE PODCASTS WITH ELDERS AND OTHER CITIZENS ON TRIBAL CULTURE, EVENTS, AND ACTIVITIES. THEY WILL INCORPORATE PODCASTS INTO THE MOBILE RESOURCE LIBRARY AND SHARE WITH AUDIENCES OF ALL AGES. THE PROJECT WILL HELP WITH PANDEMIC RECOVERY BY PROVIDING ACCESS TO PROGRAMMING THAT WAS LIMITED OR ELIMINATED DUE TO COVID-19 RESTRICTIONS AND THAT DIRECTLY SERVES MEMBERS OF THE COMMUNITY.

THE BLUE LAKE RANCHERIA SYLVIA DANIELS MEMORIAL LIBRARY IN CALIFORNIA WILL EXPAND ITS PROGRAMMING TO BRING CULTURE, INNOVATION, AND LEARNING OPPORTUNITIES TO THE RURAL AREAS OF HUMBOLDT COUNTY. COVID-19 HIGHLIGHTED CHALLENGES AROUND THE LACK OF TECHNOLOGICAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND READINESS FOR VIRTUAL LEARNING, LEADING TO STRESS AND ANXIETY. PROGRAMS DEVELOPED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH BLUE LAKE RANCHERIA TRIBAL EDUCATION AGENCY WILL EMPHASIZE YOUTH AND FAMILY LITERACY AND MENTAL HEALTH. THE WISDOM BASKET MOBILE LIBRARY VAN WILL VISIT OUTLYING RURAL AREAS ONCE A MONTH TO SHARE LITERACY, ARTS AND CRAFTS, STEM, AND CULTURAL ACTIVITIES WITH SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES. DURING THE VAN'S VISIT, CHILDREN CAN BORROW BACKPACKS FILLED WITH AGE-APPROPRIATE BOOKS, WHICH THEY CAN RETURN THE FOLLOWING MONTH. THE LIBRARY WILL PRODUCE VIDEOS TO POST ON A YOUTUBE CHANNEL FEATURING CONTENT ON ELDER-INSTRUCTED CULTURAL ARTS SUCH AS BASKET MAKING, BEADING, TRADITIONAL COOKING, AND STORYTELLING.

THE NEZ PERCE TRIBE IN LAPWAI, IDAHO, IS WORKING TO HIGHLIGHT THE MEANINGFUL RETURN OF A SIGNIFICANT COLLECTION OF TREASURED ARTIFACTS TO THE TRIBE AND THE RECENT RENAMING CEREMONY HONORING THOSE ITEMS. THE WETXUUWOITIN COLLECTION OF SACRED NEZ PERCE CLOTHING AND RELATED ITEMS IS ONE OF THE FEW REMAINING AND MOST COMPLETE COLLECTIONS OF NATIVE AMERICAN CLOTHING ARTIFACTS DATING FROM PRE-1840. THEY PLAN TO ESTABLISH A READING/RESEARCH LIBRARY ON TRIBE-OWNED PROPERTY ADJACENT TO THE NATIONAL NEZ PERCE INTERPRETIVE CENTER TO ENCOURAGE VISITORS TO LEARN MORE ABOUT NEZ PERCE CULTURE. AT THE SAME TIME, THEY WILL RECRUIT A QUALIFIED CURATOR OR HISTORIAN TO DEVELOP A SIGNATURE PROJECT RELATED TO THE WETXUUWOITIN COLLECTION. FINALLY, THEY PLAN TO ORGANIZE FOUR COMMUNITY WORKSHOPS SHOWCASING SKILLS EVIDENCED IN THE COLLECTION ARTIFACTS. THIS PROJECT WILL HELP THE NEZ PERCE RECOVER FROM THE ISOLATION CAUSED BY THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, USING THE CONNECTION TO TRIBAL HERITAGE AS A MEANS OF COMMUNITY EMPOWERMENT, RECOVERY, AND RESILIENCY.

THE CEMONIA STROTHER LIBRARY, SERVING A TRIBAL COMMUNITY OF 1450 AND SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES, WILL USE GRANT FUNDS TO INCREASE TRIBAL CAPACITY TO PROVIDE MEANINGFUL LIBRARY RESOURCES THAT ADDRESS EDUCATIONAL AND EMPLOYMENT BARRIERS TO IMPROVE THE LIVES OF TRIBAL CITIZENS. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC, MANY TRIBAL MEMBERS FACED FINANCIAL HARDSHIPS DUE TO LOST JOBS AND RESULTED IN LOST RESOURCES, THAT INCLUDED THE INTERNET. BY ADDING A STAFF PERSON, ACCESSING PROFESSIONAL TRAINING TO RESPOND TO COMMUNITY NEEDS, AND IMPROVING LIBRARY RESOURCES, THE CEMONIA STROTHER LIBRARY AIMS TO RETURN AND IMPROVE ON ITS VALUE TO THE COMMUNITY.

THE FORT MCDOWELL TRIBAL LIBRARY IN FOUNTAIN HILLS, ARIZONA, WILL STRENGTHEN ITS ONLINE CULTURAL AND LEARNING PLATFORMS, WHICH USERS HAVE ACCESSED ON AN UNPRECEDENTED SCALE SINCE THE ONSET OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE LIBRARY WILL PUBLISH A YAVAPAI DICTIONARY IN THE FORM OF A MOBILE APPLICATION, CONVERT YAVAPAI LANGUAGE CDS FEATURING TRIBAL ELDERS TO MORE VERSATILE DIGITAL FORMATS, AND OFFER A YAVAPAI LANGUAGE CAMP FOR SCHOOL-AGE STUDENTS. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL EXPAND ITS COLLECTION OF E-BOOKS. FINALLY, THE LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE LAPTOPS AND INTERNET HOTSPOTS FOR USE BY STUDENTS AND COMMUNITY MEMBERS. THESE ACTIVITIES WILL HELP THE YAVAPAI COMMUNITY RECOVER AND PRIORITIZE CULTURE PRESERVATION AFTER THE DEVASTATING PANDEMIC.

THE MENOMINEE INDIAN TRIBAL ARCHIVES AND THE MENOMINEE CULTURAL MUSEUM IN KESHENA, WISCONSIN, WILL COLLABORATE ON A PROJECT TO IMPROVE MANAGEMENT, CARE, AND TRIBAL MEMBER ACCESS TO ARCHIVAL AND ETHNOGRAPHIC COLLECTIONS. THEY WILL HIRE AND TRAIN TWO PART-TIME STAFF TO SELECT, CATALOG, AND REHOUSE COLLECTION MATERIALS. OTHER MUSEUM STAFF WILL RECEIVE TRAININGS ON ARCHIVAL SOFTWARE AND COLLECTIONS CARE AND MANAGEMENT. THE TRIBAL ARCHIVIST WILL MANAGE THE PROJECT, WHICH IS PART OF A LONG-TERM EFFORT TO PROVIDE TRIBAL MEMBERS WITH DIGITAL ACCESS TO A BROAD ARRAY OF CULTURAL HERITAGE MATERIALS, AND WAS DELAYED AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC'S EFFECTS ON COLLECTIONS STEWARDSHIP.

THE JAMESTOWN S'KLALLAM TRIBE IN SEQUIM, WASHINGTON, WILL INCREASE AWARENESS OF AND EXPAND ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTIONS, WHICH TELL THE HISTORY OF THE JAMESTOWN S'KLALLAM PEOPLE. THE TRIBAL LIBRARIAN WILL CATALOGUE SIX ARCHAEOLOGICAL COLLECTIONS INCLUDING APPROXIMATELY 200,000 ARTIFACTS, MOST OF WHICH ARE NOT CURRENTLY AVAILABLE TO THE PUBLIC IN PHYSICAL FORM. THE LIBRARIAN WILL CROSS-REFERENCE APPROXIMATELY 1,500 OF THE ITEMS WITH THEIR DIGITAL REPRESENTATIONS IN THE HOUSE OF SEVEN GENERATIONS, THE TRIBE'S VIRTUAL MUSEUM AND ARCHIVE. THIS COLLECTION DIGITIZATION PROJECT WILL PROVIDE REMOTE PUBLIC ACCESS TO THE COLLECTION DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AND INCREASE THE JAMESTOWN S'KLALLAM TRIBE'S PHYSICAL AND INTELLECTUAL CONTROL OF THEIR COLLECTIONS. THE TRIBE WILL ORGANIZE AN ONLINE EVENT SHOWCASING THE COLLECTION, AS WELL AS GUIDED TOURS OF THE PHYSICAL ARCHIVES FOR TRIBAL MEMBERS.

THE BEN GUTHRIE-LAC DE FLAMBEAU PUBLIC LIBRARY SERVES THE LAC DE FLAMBEAU BAND OF LAKE SUPERIOR CHIPPEWA INDIANS AND NON-NATIVES IN NORTHERN WISCONSIN. MODERN LIBRARY TECHNOLOGY ONLY RECENTLY ARRIVED AT THE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN 2018. DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC AS MORE DAILY ACTIVITIES WERE BEING SWITCHED TO VIRTUAL EVENTS, AND IT SOON BECAME OBVIOUS THAT MANY NEEDED ASSISTANCE ACCESSING AND LEARNING THE NEW TECHNOLOGIES AND METHODS TO RECEIVE SERVICES. ADDITIONALLY, PEOPLE HAD MORE TIME ON THEIR HANDS AND LEARNED NEW HOBBIES, SKILLS, AND COMPLETED HOME TASKS. GRANT MONEY FROM THE AMERICAN RESCUE PLAN WILL ENABLE THE LIBRARY TO PROVIDE NEEDED COMPUTER SKILLS TRAINING AND ZOOM INSTRUCTION FOR LIBRARY PATRONS AS WELL AS PROVIDE A SPACE WHERE CITIZENS CAN BUILD COMMUNITY THROUGH SHARING THEIR NEWFOUND SKILLS AND HOBBIES.

THE ONEIDA NATION OF WISCONSIN WILL REBUILD ITS LIBRARY OPERATIONS THAT WERE CURTAILED AS A RESULT OF THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. DURING THE HEIGHT OF THE PANDEMIC, THE ONEIDA NATION WAS FORCED TO CUT STAFF AND REDUCE HOURS AND SERVICES AT THE MAIN BRANCH OF ITS LIBRARY (THE ONEIDA COMMUNITY LIBRARY), WHERE ONLY CURBSIDE PICKUP WAS AVAILABLE FOR PATRONS. THE TRIBE'S GREEN EARTH LIBRARY BRANCH WAS CLOSED COMPLETELY DURING THIS TIME. THE MAIN BRANCH NOW WILL REOPEN FULLY, WITH CURBSIDE PICKUP AVAILABLE AT THE GREEN EARTH LIBRARY BRANCH. THE LIBRARIES ALSO WILL DEVELOP EDUCATIONAL AND LITERACY PROGRAMMING TO HELP CLOSE EDUCATION GAPS CREATED BY THE PANDEMIC.

LOCATED IN SOUTH-CENTRAL OKLAHOMA, THE CHICKASAW NATION DIVISION OF HISTORY AND CULTURE WILL INSTALL A CUSTOM EXHIBIT CASE AT FORT WASHITA TO APPROPRIATELY DISPLAY HISTORICAL TRIBAL ARTIFACTS. FORT WASHITA IS AN IMPORTANT HISTORICAL LOCATION FOR THE CHICKASAW PEOPLE. AFTER CLOSING AND REDUCING SERVICES DURING COVID-19, FORT WASHITA IS PREPARING TO REOPEN TO THE GENERAL PUBLIC. THIS PLANNED EXHIBIT CASE WILL DISPLAY CULTURAL ARTIFACTS THAT ARE CURRENTLY IN STORAGE. THIS EXHIBIT CASE WILL ALSO ALLOW FOR CONTINUED SOCIAL DISTANCING AND A SAFE ENVIRONMENT FOR CHICKASAW CITIZENS, SCHOOLS, AND VISITORS FROM SURROUNDING COMMUNITIES TO FORT WASHITA BEGINNING MAY 2022.

THE VILLAGE OF ANGOON, ALASKA, HOME TO THE DEISHEETAN CLAN OF THE TLINGIT TRIBE WILL CREATE AN ARTISTS' WORKSHOP WITH A LIBRARY AND RESOURCE CENTER THAT WILL HELP THIS REMOTE COMMUNITY ADDRESS THE SOCIAL ISOLATION AND LACK OF ACCESS TO CULTURAL ACTIVITIES THAT HAVE RESULTED FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. THE ARTISTS' WORKSHOP WILL PROVIDE A SPACE WHERE LOCAL CARVERS, WEAVERS, BEADERS, AND PAINTERS CAN WORK ON THEIR CRAFTS AND OFFER SMALL GROUP AND ONE-ON-ONE CLASSES. THE WORKSHOP ALSO WILL INCLUDE A DESIGNATED LIBRARY AND RESOURCE CENTER WHERE COMMUNITY MEMBERS, VISITORS, AND ARTISTS CAN EXPLORE MATERIALS ABOUT TLINGIT CARVING, DRAWING, BEADING, AND WEAVING. THESE PROGRAMS WILL HELP TRIBAL YOUTH, FAMILIES, AND ELDERS RECONNECT WITH THEIR RICH CULTURE AND HISTORY.

THE NOOKSACK TRIBAL LIBRARY WILL PURCHASE A YEAR SUBSCRIPTION FOR SEVEN RESEARCH DATABASES THROUGH PROQUEST TO THEN BE ACCESSIBLE BY THE TRIBAL LIBRARY COMPUTERS. DATABASE SUBSCRIPTIONS INCREASE THE ABILITIES OF SMALL LIBRARIES AND PROVIDE A SERVICE THAT CONTRIBUTES TO THE LEARNING AND WELL-BEING OF STUDENTS, FAMILIES, AND INDIVIDUALS FROM ALL BACKGROUNDS. IT PARTICULARLY SUPPORTS THE CREATION AND DELIVERY OF ONLINE AND IN PERSON EDUCATIONAL OPPORTUNITIES FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES. HAVING ACCESS TO THIS NEW LIBRARY FEATURE WILL HELP STUDENTS LEARN HOW TO RESEARCH AND USE DATABASES PROPERLY, IN A WAY THAT IS NO LONGER LIMITED BY THE SCHOOL SHUTDOWNS CAUSED BY COVID-19.

THE WYANDOTTE NATION CULTURAL CENTER AND MUSEUM IN OKLAHOMA WILL EXPAND ITS OUTREACH TO BROADER COMMUNITIES BY CREATING AN ONLINE EXHIBIT FEATURING PHOTOGRAPHS, PAINTINGS, AND OTHER WYANDOTTE ARTIFACTS. THE MUSEUM WILL HIRE A MUSEUM TECHNICIAN WHO WILL RECEIVE INSTRUCTION FROM THE STATE HISTORICAL SOCIETY ON BEST PRACTICES IN ONLINE EXHIBITS. THE ONLINE EXHIBIT WILL ALLOW THE MUSEUM TO SERVE WYANDOTTE CITIZENS ALL OVER THE COUNTRY, PROVIDING THEM WITH ACCESS TO ITS COLLECTION AND RELATED EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS. THE PROJECT WILL HELP COMMUNITIES RECOVER FROM THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC BY ALLOWING CITIZENS TO PRACTICE SOCIAL DISTANCING WHILE CREATING A DIGITAL COMMUNITY. IN ADDITION TO INCREASING ACCESS TO TRIBAL HERITAGE, THE MUSEUM'S ONLINE PRESENCE WILL ENHANCE CONNECTIONS WITH THE TRIBE AND TRIBAL CITIZENS NATIONWIDE.

THE IRENE INGLE PUBLIC LIBRARY IN WRANGELL, ALASKA, WILL EXPAND ITS OPERATING HOURS TO BETTER SERVE PATRONS ON A MORE REGULAR BASIS. THE LIBRARY WAS LOOKING TO FILL A VACANT STAFF POSITION WHEN IT WAS FORCED TO SHUT DOWN IN MARCH 2020 DUE TO THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. WHEN THE LIBRARY REOPENED ALMOST 3 MONTHS LATER, IT DECREASED THE HOURS IT WAS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC FROM 38 A WEEK TO 20. BY HIRING A LIBRARY ASSISTANT, THE LIBRARY NOW WILL BE ABLE TO BETTER SERVE THE COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING SERVICES FOR AN ADDITIONAL 15 HOURS PER WEEK, INCLUDING ON THE WEEKENDS. AS COVID-19 RECOVERY CONTINUES, THE LIBRARY WILL SERVE AS A TRUSTED PLACE FOR COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT.

THE PUEBLO OF POJOAQUE IN SANTA FE, NEW MEXICO, WILL IMPLEMENT A PROJECT TO STRENGTHEN AND REBUILD COMMUNITY TIES THROUGH INNOVATIVE DIGITAL MATERIALS THAT DOCUMENT THE SHARED HISTORY OF THE POJOAQUE PUEBLO PEOPLE. THE PANDEMIC HIGHLIGHTED A CRUCIAL NEED FOR GREATER ONLINE PROGRAMMING, ACCESS, AND LITERACY AMONG THE PUEBLO PEOPLE, WHO EXPERIENCED EXTREME ISOLATION CAUSED BY SOCIAL DISTANCING AND QUARANTINE. DRAWING FROM RESOURCES IN THE POEH CULTURAL CENTER ARCHIVE, WHICH IS DEDICATED TO SUSTAINING TEWA TRADITIONS, A SERIES OF APPROXIMATELY 2,000 DIGITAL FILES WILL BE CREATED USING PHOTOGRAPHS AND STILL IMAGES AND WILL BE INCLUDED IN A SEARCHABLE, PUBLICLY ACCESSIBLE DATABASE. AN INTERACTIVE WEBPAGE ON THE POEH WEBSITE WILL ENABLE COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO UPLOAD DIGITIZED IMAGES AND SHARE STORIES.

THE HULA PRESERVATION SOCIETY IN KANEOHE, HAWAII, WILL EXPAND ITS DIGITAL LITERACY TOOLS AND ONLINE SERVICES TO BUILD DIGITAL LITERACY AMONG ITS PATRONS, SUCH AS BY CREATING AND SHARING 10 NEW DIGITAL PRODUCTS ONLINE. THE SOCIETY WILL CREATE NINE VIDEO-BASED TUTORIALS (EACH 5 TO 10 MINUTES IN LENGTH) ON TOPICS SUCH AS HOW TO USE THE SOCIETY'S ORAL HISTORY TOOLS AND TRANSCRIPTS AND ITS DATABASE REPOSITORY FOR RESEARCH PURPOSES. THE SOCIETY'S YOUTUBE CHANNEL WILL HOST VIDEOS OF THE TUTORIALS, AND A NEW TUTORIALS CHANNEL WILL BE CREATED ON THE SOCIETY'S VIMEO SITE. A NEW DIGITAL RESOURCE GUIDE WILL FACILITATE USERS' QUICK, EFFECTIVE, AND RESPONSIBLE USE OF ALL OF THE SOCIETY'S ONLINE MATERIALS. THESE EFFORTS WILL ADDRESS A NEED CLARIFIED DURING THE PANDEMIC TO STRENGTHEN AND EXPAND ONLINE SERVICES AND DIGITAL LITERACY TOOLS IN SUPPORT OF THE COMMUNITY.

THE QUAPAW TRIBAL LIBRARY IN OKLAHOMA WILL USE LESSONS LEARNED AROUND THE CONSEQUENCES OF FORCED ISOLATION DURING THE PANDEMIC AND THE IMPLICATIONS OF THE DIGITAL DIVIDE TO EXPAND PROGRAMS AND SERVICES TO REACH MORE TRIBAL MEMBERS AND THE COMMUNITY AT LARGE. THE LIBRARY WILL IMPLEMENT A SERIES OF TRADITIONAL NATIVE AMERICAN CRAFT COURSES TO FOSTER LIFELONG LEARNING, PROMOTE THE RICH HERITAGE OF THE QUAPAW, AND ENSURE THAT TRADITIONAL ARTS AND CRAFTS OF NATIVE AMERICANS ARE NOT LOST. A SERIES OF COURSES ALSO WILL PROVIDE AREA YOUTH WITH EFFECTIVE STEAM EDUCATION THROUGH HIGH-QUALITY, RIGOROUS, AND AUTHENTIC LEARNING EXPERIENCES. ALL COURSES WILL BE VIDEOTAPED AND AVAILABLE ONLINE FOR THOSE WHO CANNOT ATTEND IN PERSON.

THE YAKAMA NATION LIBRARY IN TOPPENISH, WASHINGTON, WILL EXPAND ITS CAPABILITY TO PROVIDE INTERNET CONNECTIVITY FOR TRIBAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO DO NOT HAVE ACCESS AT HOME. THE LIBRARY WILL HIRE A TECHNOLOGY REVIEW CONSULTANT TO CONDUCT A TECHNOLOGY SITE SURVEY SO IT CAN PLAN AND EVALUATE THE BEST APPROACH FOR IMPLEMENTING THE EXPANDED INTERNET PROJECT AND SUSTAINING A ROBUST ONLINE ENVIRONMENT. THEY ALSO PLAN TO EXPAND WI-FI ACCESS BY PURCHASING UPGRADED EQUIPMENT THAT ENABLES FASTER, BROADER CONNECTIVITY. EXISTING TV WHITE SPACE EQUIPMENT WILL PROVIDE WI-FI TO NEARBY TRIBAL COMMUNITY HOUSING AREAS AND BUILDINGS. THE PROJECT WILL ASSIST WITH COVID-19 RECOVERY BY FILLING INTERNET ACCESS GAPS THAT ARE ESSENTIAL FOR EDUCATION, EMPLOYMENT AND HEALTH-RELATED NEEDS.

THE ONEIDA INDIAN NATION LIBRARY IN NEW YORK WILL EXPAND PROGRAMS AND SERVICES AS THE COMMUNITY RECOVERS FROM A PERIOD OF COVID-19 RESTRICTIONS AND CLOSURE. HOUSED WITHIN THE RAY ELM CHILDREN AND ELDERS CENTER, THE LIBRARY SUSTAINS THE CULTURAL HERITAGE OF THE ONEIDA PEOPLE. THE LIBRARY ADMINISTRATOR WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN ANNUAL SERVICE PLAN THAT INCLUDES ONLINE AND IN-PERSON EDUCATION, INTERPRETIVE AND EXPERIENTIAL PROGRAMS, AND EXHIBITIONS FOR LEARNERS OF ALL AGES. THE LIBRARY ALSO WILL RESUME ITS GENERAL OPERATIONS, INCORPORATING PROCESSES AND PROCEDURES THAT WERE ADOPTED TO MAINTAIN HEALTH AND SAFETY DURING THE PANDEMIC.

CHIPPEWA CREE TRIBE (CCT), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH STONE CHILD COLLEGE (SCC), WILL ENHANCE TRIBAL CULTURAL KNOWLEDGE BY INCREASING THE VOLUME OF, AND COMMUNITY ACCESS TO, CULTURAL ARCHIVAL MATERIALS. THIS ONE-YEAR PROJECT WILL INCREASE TRIBAL HISTORY AND LANGUAGE PRESERVATION BY: ANALYZING, CATEGORIZING, AND ARCHIVING AN ESTIMATED 45,000 PIECES OF DOCUMENTS AND PHOTOS; POSTING REGULAR UPDATES ON CCT/SCC SOCIAL MEDIA WHILE PROMOTING THE PROJECT GOALS AND AVAILABILITY OF ARCHIVED MATERIALS; AND INCREASING THE PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT AMONG LIBRARY STAFF, FOCUSING ON SPECIFIC DIGITAL LIBRARY TRAINING. THE PROJECT WILL ENHANCE LIBRARY SERVICES AND PROMOTE INTEREST IN COMMUNITY MEMBER KNOWLEDGE AND APPRECIATION FOR TRIBAL HERITAGE AND CULTURE, ESPECIALLY BY USING DIGITAL INNOVATION TO INCREASE INTEREST AND ACCESSIBILITY TO NEW GENERATIONS OF TRIBAL MEMBERS.

THE ORGANIZED VILLAGE OF KAKE, A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED ALASKAN TRIBE, WILL TRANSFORM THE TRIBE'S ARCHIVAL COLLECTION FROM A LIBRARY-ONLY VERSION TO AN EASY-TO-USE, PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ONLINE PLATFORM TO HELP THE COMMUNITY FOSTER POSITIVE AND LASTING IMPROVEMENTS AND COMBAT SOME OF THE SOCIAL AND CULTURAL ISOLATION IT HAS FACED DURING THE COVID-19 PANDEMIC. MANY OF THE TRIBE'S ARCHIVED AUDIO AND VIDEO RECORDINGS CONTAIN CONTENT ON CULTURAL SURVIVAL, COMMUNITY SELF-RELIANCE, IDENTITY FORMATION, CULTURAL VALUES OF SELF-WORTH AND RESPECT, AND TRIBAL LAW. THE ARCHIVE WILL RECONNECT YOUTH AND FAMILIES WITH THE RICH TLINGOT HISTORY AND CULTURE OF THE PEOPLE OF KAKE AND ALLOW THE COMMUNITY TO EXPAND AND SHARE ITS ARCHIVAL COLLECTIONS TO BUILD AND SUSTAIN A STRONG AND RESILIENT COMMUNITY THAT KNOWS ITS STORIES AND HISTORY AND EXHIBITS THE VALUES THAT HAVE HELPED THE COMMUNITY THRIVE FOR MILLENNIA.
